exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following represents a positive change of pregnancy
options: Morning sickness
Quickening
Positive pregnancy test
Foetal heart beat auscultated with Doppler

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Maria aged 24 years, is a 3 month primagravida, visiting ante natal clinic for the first time. Maria is concerned that she has not put on any weight. The most appropriate advice would be
options: Due to the babies requirements you need to eat more
You need to exercise less or you stress the baby
There is no need to put on weight in the first trimester
Rest more and eat more carbohydrates

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In order to prevent infection of hepatitis B virus, the pregnant woman should
options: Receive gamma globulin during the first trimester
Carefully wash hands before eating or preparing food
Receive the hepatitis B vaccine
Take AZT during the second and third trimester

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following represents a recommended weight gain during pregnancy
options: 6 to 11 kgs
11 to 16 kgs
13 to 18 kgs
18 to 20 kgs

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks gestation exhibits a rise in her baseline systolic blood pressure of 32 mm Hg, a weight gain of 4 kgs since last week and difficulty removing rings she normally wears. This is suggestive of a) Gestational hypertenision
options: Pre eclampsia
Eclampsia
Elevated liver enzymes

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The primary pathophysiologic basis for the clinical manifestations of pregnancy induced hypertension (PIH) is
options: Fluid retention related to excessive salt intake
Ineffective excretion of fluid by the kidneys
Cardiac decompenstion
Ineffective dilatation of the vascular network to accommodate the expanding blood volume of pregnancy

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which measure would be least effective in relieving the signs and symptoms of mild pre eclampsia
options: Low salt diet
Period of bed rest
Balanced diet with protein
Relaxation techniques

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A woman with severe pre eclampsia is being monitored for assessment findings indicative of cerebral oedema and venospasm. Which of the following would you not expect to find
options: Hypotonic deep tendon reflexes
Headache
Vision changes including blurring and spots before the eyes
Insomnia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Newly expectant parents, ask the nurse how they can prepare their 3yr old preschool daughter for the new baby. All of the following would be useful expect
options: tell the child about the pregnancy as soon as mother begins to look pregnant
Arrange for a few sleep overs with the person who will care for the child at the time of the birth
Transfer their child to her new room and bed just before the expected birth of the baby
Introduce their child to preschool as soon as possible

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Inability to chew might result from damage to which cranial nerve
options: Facial
Trigeminal
Abducens
Vagus

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In most people, the left cerebral hemisphere is more important for which of the following
options: Spoken and written language
Space and pattern perception
Musical and artistic awareness
Imagination

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is true concerning the limbic system
options: It is comprised of parts of the cerebrum and diencephalon
It assumes a primary function in emotions
Both a and b
Neither a nor b

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Cooridination of muscular activity is a function of the
options: Cerebral peduncles
Cerebellum
Thalamus
Medulla oblongata

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following statements is correct
options: Appetite control is a function of the thalamus
The midbrain is a conduction pathway and reflex center
The cerebellum has sensory centers for thirst and speech
Respiratory centers are located in the basal ganglia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The structure that connects the cerebral hemispheres and facilitates the sharing of cerebral information is the a) Corpus callosum
options: Cingulated sulcus
Fourth ventricle
Aqueduct of sylvius

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The portion of bone laid down first in bone formation is the
options: Matrix
Calcium salts
Trabeculae
Marrow

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What is the most common cause of heart failure (HF)
options: Smoking
Diabetes
Coronary artery disease
Family history

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The action of ACE inhibitors (angiotensin converting enzyme) is
options: Increased urinary output, therefore decreased blood pressure
Relax blood vessels, therefore decreased vascular resistance
Strengthens cardiac contraction, therefore increase cardiac output
Relax cardiac muscle, therefore decrease heart rate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Hyperkalemia is
options: Increased serum potassium levels
Increased serum calcium levels
Increased red blood cell count
Increased serum chloride levels

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Manifestations of heart failure are
options: Hepatomeglia, pitted dependent edema
Increased serum glucose levels
Increased appetite and weight gain
Decreased respiration and dyspnea

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Nursing interventions associated with your clients taking loop diuretics such as frusimide are
options: Blood sugar levels, dietary fibre
Monitoring of weight and K+ levels
Blood pressure and urinary output
Make sure your client eats ½ hour following administration

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Loop diuretics act by
options: Increasing the blood flow to the glomerular network
Decreasing the blood flow to the kidneys therefore decreased urinary output
Increased H20 reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules of the nephron
Inhibition complex active pump mechanism therefore increase excretion of electrolytes

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The primary ossification center of long bone is located in which of the following structures
options: Ephipysis
Epiphyseal plate
Diaphysis
Endosterum

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The body tissues affected by rheumatoid arthritis is
options: Adipose
Muscular
Connective
Epithelial

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The pattern of rheumatoid arthritis is best described by its
options: Chronicity
Remissions and exacerbations
Little relief from aches and pains
A progressive increase in disability

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by
options: Bone pain
Sharp tingling sensations
Inflammation of the joints
Pain and swelling of joints

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Synovial joints are characterized by
options: Articular cartilage
Fibrous capsule
Joint cavity
All of these

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The major support that the muscular system gets from the cardiovascular system
options: A direct response by controlling the heart rate and the respiratory rate
Constriction of blood vessels and decrease in heart rate for thermoregulatory control
Nutrient and oxygen delivery and carbon dioxide removal
Decreased volume of blood and rate of flow for maximal muscle contraction

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Manifestations of right sided heart failure are
options: Fatigue, cyamosis, blood tinged sputum
Anorexia, complaints of gastrointestinal distress, fatigue and pitted edema
Dyspnea, orthopnea and cyanosis
Fatigue dependant edema and cough

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Nursing intervention necessary prior to the administration of digoxin is
options: Palpation of arterial pulse less than 60 beats/minute
Palpation of venous pulse less than 60 beats/minute
Palpation of arterial pulse greater than 60 beats/minute
Palpation of pedal pulse less than 60 beats/minute

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Left sided heart failure affects directly the
options: Liver and extremities
Lungs
Level of consciousness
Lungs and extremities

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Basic nursing objectives in the treatment of HF are
options: Start heparinization immediately
Nursing the client in trendlenberg position
Promote rest therefore decrease workload on heart and decrease H20 accumulation
Assess levels of consciousness and give 02 61/min via Hudson mask

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Define a cerebral vascular accident (CVA)
options: Sudden loss of consciousness due to a decreased contractility of the cardia
Loss of brain function due to disruption of blood supply to the brain
Intermittent spasms of blood vessels interrupting blood flow to the brain
Neurologic dysfunction due to diminished blood flow to the cranium

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Cerebral thrombosis is
options: Most common cause of a stroke
Originates from a large vessel and lodges in the brain
May be caused by an arterial spasm in the brain
Usually occurs during strenuous exercise

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Risk factors of CVA that cannot be altered are
options: Sex, race and raised blood cholesterol levels
High BP, previous TIA
Race, prior stroke and overweight
High BP, previous TIA and increased blood cholesterol levels

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A person who has experienced a right CVA may present with
options: Receptive or expressive aphasia
Right hemiplegia
Left hemiplegia
Deficit of new language information *left temporal lobe -> wernicke -> language and speech sound comprehension *left frontal lobe -> broca’s -> vital role in generation of articulate speech

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Where and what is the circle of willis
options: A capillary meshwork found in bowmans capsule of the nephron
A vascular network at the base of the brain
A roundabout at the top[ of bank st
The capsule membrane of a malignant growth

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: List the 3 main causes of stroke
options: Cerebral haemorrhage, thrombosis, embolism
Cerebral thrombosis, infarction, aneurysm
Cerebral embolism, metastatic lesions, coagulopathy
Cerebral ischemia, vascular spasms, hypoxia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Angina symptoms include
options: Radiating pain, decreased BP and increased pulse
Shortness of breath, loss of consciousness and these effects may last indefinitely
Ringing in the ears, anxiety and cramping in the extremities
Shortness of breath, sweating, nausea and tiredness

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Emphysema is
options: An alveolar disease
Due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of bronchial glands
Persistent episodes of productive cough
An airway disease

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The term blue bloater refers to
options: Decreased erythropoietin production therefore decreased 02 carrying capability of the RBC
Polycythemia and cyanosis from right ventricular failure
Cyanosis due to decreased RBC production
Increased BP due to high blood volume or fluid overload

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Bronchitis is
options: Results from a breakdown in the normal lung defence mechanisms
Destruction of alveolar
Due to enlarged terminal non respiratory bronchioles and alveolar walls
History of daily productive cough that last at lease 3 months, for 2 years

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Emphysema is characterised by
options: Fat people due to decreased activity tolerance
Unproductive cough and pursed lip breathing
Pursed lip breathing and productive cough
Blue bloater, normal skin colour and rapid respirations

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Nursing interventions for the CORD patient include everyone of these except
options: Improve ventilation
Remove secretions
Prevent complications
Promote cooperation and understanding
Encourage exercise to test tolerance levels

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Bronchodilators
options: Aid the movement of secretions
Liquefy the sputum therefore increase expectoration
Include aminophylline for the acute exacerbation
Are only used in emergency cases

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Corticosteroids are used
options: Prophylactically in most cases
To aid in vitamin D synthesis
To aid the liquefaction and expectoration of sputum
Used during the acute exacerbation of CORD

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The foetal presenting part is described as vertex when the
options: Face enters the pelvis first
Buttocks emerge with legs extended over the abdomen
Flexed head enters pelvis first
Foetal lie is longitudinal

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When examining the umbilical cord immediately after birth the nurse should expect to observe
options: One artery
Two veins
Whitish grey colouration
Slight odour

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Vitamin K is given to the newborn to
options: Reduce bilirubin levels
Increase the production of red blood cells
Stimulate the formation of surfactant
Enhance the ability of the blood to clot

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse is performing a 5 minute apgar on a newborn. Which of the following observations is included in the apgar score a) blood pressure
options: Temperature
Muscle tone
Weight

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: At birth the major cause of heat loss is by
options: Evaporation
Radiation
Conduction
Convection

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Following the birth of graces baby, a healthy male, you are assisting grace to feed her baby for the first time. The action of prolactin at this time a) Immediately stimulates full milk production
options: Stimulates involution
Is inhibited until progesterone and oestrogen levels have decreased
Is not influenced by other hormones

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A newborns birth weight is 3400 grms. The maximum expected weight loss for this newborn would be a) 170 gms
options: 340 gms
510 gms
680 gms

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The birth weight of a breast feed newborn was 3600 grms. On the third day the newborns weight was 3350 grms. The nurse should
options: Encourage the mother to continue breast feeding as her babys nutrient and fluid needs are brin met
Suggest that the mother switch to bottle feeding as breast feeding is ineffective in meeting her babys needs
Notify the doctor as the baby has lost too much weight
Refer the mother to a lactation consultant to improve her breastfeeding technique

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following would be an unexpected sign of dehydration in the newborn
options: Weight loss
Reduced turgor
Concentrated urine
Decreased frequency and amount of urine

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A breast fed baby will have bowel motions
options: That are yellow and runny at least twice a day
May go 2-3 days without a bowel motion
Will pas meconium for a shorter period
Establishes a very regular pattern of bowel motions

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Supplementary fluids for babies
options: Are advisable to prevent jaundice
Are needed for the baby under phototherapy
May be required if the mother has had a caesarean section
Are unlikely to be needed if the mother is breast feeding

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Lucy is charted 5 mls of augmentin ‘125’ T.D.S. you notice the doctor hasn’t signed the order form. A senior colleague tells you to give it. You respond by a) Giving the medication as ordered
options: Contacting the doctor to sign the order
Asking lucy if the doctor told her she would have this
Signing the form for the doctor

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The augmentin is given to lucy. she is found to be allergic when she exhibits
options: Tinnitus and vertigo
Wheezing and urticaria
Abdominal cramps and diarrhoea
Blurred vision and ataxia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jack is 15 years old. He is admitted to the hospital after briefly loosing consciousness when tackled during a rugby game. Which of the following is an indication of increasing intracranial pressure
options: Change in his level of consciousness
Anorexia and thirst
Increased pulse and respiration rates
Blurred vision and halos around lights

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jack has had two seizures while hospitalised. These have been controlled by anticonvulsant medications. Jack and his family must understand a) The medication must be taken for at least one year
options: The doctor should be seen when the prescription has finished
The medication will be discontinued on discharge
The medication will be necessary for the rest of his life

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jack is prescribed rivotril 8 mgs daily. He weighs 68 kgs. The initial doses for 2-3 days should no exceed 0.01 mgs/kg/day. Your nursing responsibility is to a) Observe for any side effects after giving the drug
options: Contact the doctor to reassess the dose prescribed
Consider his weight loss and administer the dose prescribed
Check with the charge nurse prior to administration

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Oral suspension of rivotril, 2.5 mgs per ml is available to administer 1.8 mgs you will give
options: 5.3 mls
7.2 mls

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jack is concerned about returning to school. He should be encouraged to
options: Take leave of absence for a semester
Initially, attend school only part time
Plan an alternative lifestyle
Resume all previous activities

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: James aged six weeks, is admitted with a history of frequent vomiting after feeding. The most important nursing assessment specific to this would be to observe for a) Pain in his abdomen
options: The amount and frequency of his vomits
The type of milk mixture he is having
The level of his hydration

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: His vomiting is described as projectile, this means
options: It has an unusual colour
It is a forceful vomit
It is curd like in appearance
He has frequent spills

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: James is diagnosed to have pyloric stenosis. This requires surgery to
options: Increase the opening to the pyloric sphincter
Stretch james stomach to cope with fluids
Decrease the opening in the cardiac sphincter
Put in a gastroscopy tube to bypass the stomach

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: James is prepared for surgery by
options: Having a sedative four hours pre operatively
Being hydrated with IV fluids
Amusing him to keep him alert
Feeding him on demand to keep him contented

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: James weighs 3.4 kgs. His fluid requirement is 150 ml/kg/day. To maintain his hydration james requires a) 20 mls per hour
options: 27 mls per hour
23 mls per hour
22 mls per hour

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: James mother is living in. She is breast feeding james. Nursing consideration for her should include
options: Plenty of rest and distraction
Education about breast feeding
Providing privacy and means to express milk
Checking her breasts for cracked nipples

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: James returns from theatre with an apnoea monitor. This is used to monitor
options: The rate of james breathing
The length of his sleeping
The length of time between breaths
Delays between breaths exceeding 20 seconds

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are a staff nurse working in a rehabilitation unit. Carl is 12 years old. He was involved in a road traffic accident and sustained a head injury. He has been unconscious for four weeks. You are his primary nurse. While providing his nursing care you will
options: Encourage his mother to always help you
Talk to him clearly in a normal voice
Provide him with intensive stimulation
Offer him drinks to check his swallow reflex

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: It is important to assess his level of consciousness. The first definite sign of consciousness is when
options: His eyes begin to open
His facial expression changes
He has involuntary body movement
He has plantar flexion of his feet

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Carl has a dense r) hemiplegia and some spasticity to his L) limbs. To improve his ability to ambulate in the future it is important he a) Always has his limbs extended when resting
options: Is turned to alternate sides two hourly
Has his joints flexed and rotated regularly
Maintains a healthy well balanced diet

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Carl is beginning to make progress and is relearning skills. When encouraging carls relearning of feeding you
options: Let him have a spoon and do his best
Occasionally try to tell him the right way to feed himself
Teach him in small steps and progress at his rate
Take over when he makes a mess

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Carl is learning to communicate with signals. He is using his eyes to indicate yes and no. To encourage him to use these signals you
options: Give carl a range of choices to facilitate a decision
Discontinue his care until he has communicated
Reprimand carl and explain to him he must communicate
Give two choices to facilitate decision making

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Carl is becoming irritable and communicating with loud noises which are disruptive. He reacts to visitors and the phone ringing. To help lessen this reaction you should a) Get some sedation charted for him
options: Use a mild punishment when he is disruptive
Try and find out what is really bothering him
Provide him with something interesting to quieten him

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Carl is to go home for two weeks with his family. They have bee3n visiting him 2-3 times a week and feel they can cope with him at home. In planning his discharge you would
options: Provide community contacts the family can assess
Encourage the parents to cope without help
Provide a daily schedule which is to be adhered to
Encourage the parents to phone if necessary

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Hypertension, oedema and proteinuria (GPH) syndrome commonly occurs in women who
options: Have essential hypertension
Have diabetes mellitus
Are primigravidas
All of the above

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Martin is a 6 months old, admitted in acute respiratory distress. His mother has accompanied him to hospital and is very anxious. Which isgn of repiratory distress is evident in children and not adults a) Rasping respirations
options: Slow respiratory rate
Blue peripheries
Intercostals indrawing

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Martin has a hoarse cough and is wheezing. Further assessment is important. Select the most appropriate question to initially ask his mother. a) When did martin first start coughing and wheezing
options: How long since martin last had a drink
Was martin playing with toys with small pieces
Has martin had any medication recently

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: His diagnosis is bronchiolitis. He requires oxygen therapy for at least 24 hours. Which is the most appropriate method of administration of oxygen for your client
options: Oxygen tent
Mask
Nasal prongs
Head box or cone

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which is the most important nursing observation to consider for a child having oxygen therapy
options: Monitoring his oxygen saturations regularly
Visual observation of childs respiratory status
Doing pulse and respiration recordings
Analysis of level of oxygen in the tent

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Martins mother states, im not getting enough rest here and im tired and cant cope anymore. Which is the best response to this statement a) You need to go home and rest to have a break
options: Why hasnt your family helped you with martins care
Shall i get a hospital grandparent for you
If youd like to have a break, i’ll look after martin for you

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following factors does research show most assists caregivers to cope with their childs hospitalization a) Control of decision making
options: Individualised care
Knowledge of what to expect
Time away from the child

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jenny aged 4 was brought to the emergency clinic while having an acute asthma attack. Jennys breathing would be characterized by a) Grunting inspirations
options: Wheezing on expiration
Frequent periods of apnoea
Laboured abdominal breathing

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Assisting with positive pressure breathing as ordered
options: All of these
1 and 2
1, 2 and 4
1, 3 and 4

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jenny is 3 years old, she has been admitted with acute asthma. Jenny requires IV aminophylline. It is charted at 56 mg. Each vial contains 250 mg in 10 mls. You calculate the correct dose, which is a) 3.16 mls
options: 0.4 mls
1.25 mls
2.24 mls

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jenny appears to have a secondary infection and is prescribed 375,000 units of penicillin. The vial contains 600,000 units in 2 mls. Calculate the amount jenny requires for one dose a) 1.25 mls
options: 0.32 mls

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse encourages jennys mother to stay with her as much as possible. The rationale for this is which of the following
options: Mothers of hospitalized children often experience guilt
The mothers presence will reduce anxiety and ease the childs respiratory efforts
Separation from mother is a major developmental threat at this age
The mother can provide constant observations of the childs respiratory efforts

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jenny is to have ventolin nebulisers every two hours until respirations improve. She becomes distressed as soon as you try to put the mask on her face. You would best manage this situation initially by
options: Getting her mother to assist with administration
Not giving it to her as being distressed may make her worse
Realising the importance of the ventolin so forcing it on her
Letting her have a mask to play with

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: As jennys condition improves she is to commence oral medication. Which approach is most likely to gain compliance
options: Its time for your medication now, would you like to drink it with a straw or from a glass
Wouldn’t you like to take your medicine now
You must take your medication, because the doctor says it will make you better
See how nicely Johnny took his medicine, now take yours

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The correct route of the drug
options: All of these
1, 2 and 4
1 and 4
2 and 3

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A preschooler is febrile and requires 4 hourly temperature recordings. The most appropriate method would be a) Orally
options: Rectally
Orally or axillary
Axillary

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Christina age 10 is admitted to your unit with a diagnosis of rheumatic fever. You are her primary nurse. The causative organism for rheumatic fever is a) Haemophilus influenza
options: Staphylococcus bacteria
Syncytial virus
Group a streptococcal bacteria

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The most serious complication of rheumatic fever is
options: Endocarditis
Pneumonia
Arthritis
Meningitis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Christina is admitted to your unit. You are her primary nurse. Your responsibilities will be to
options: Do an assessment and history appraisal
Orientate her to the area
Establish a trusting relationship
Do all of the above

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following would support a diagnosis of chickenpox
options: Chills, headache, malaise
Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea
Kopliks spots, photo phobia, fever
Sore throat, chills, fever

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are a practice nurse and kevins mother asks for advice on how to care for Kevin at home. Aims of care for Kevin are a) Ensure rest and relieve itching
options: Maintain hydration and isolate Kevin
Maintain hydration and relieve itching
Ensure rest and isolate Kevin

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Kevins mother asks you when she can send him back to kindergarten. You advise
options: When all spots have gone
In one weeks time if temperature is normal
He is not contagious now spots have appeared
When all spots are dry and crusted

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Kevins mother asks you why the chicken pox immunisation is not offered as part of the immunisation programme
options: There is no vaccine for chickenpox
There are no major sequelae of chicken pox
The public would not accept another immunisation

The vaccine for chicken pox is too expensive *I think this is an outdated question -> chickenpox vaccine -> varicella (verivax) at 15 months, is given to individuals 12 months and older. At risk children are at 2 years

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are a practice nurse. Dannys mother phones you. Danny is 18 months old. She is concerned over his difficulty with respirations and ‘barking’ cough. You suspect he may have laryngotracheobronchitis (croup). The characteristic crowing sound of respirations in croup is a) Stridor
options: Rhonchi
Wheeze
Rales

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following comments by dannys mother most strongly supports a diagnosis of croup
options: Hes been very lethargic and drowsy these last few days
His older sister has bad asthma since she was 7 years old
He seems to cough much more when hes lying down
He had the flu a week ago

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Dannys mother should be instructed to watch for signs of worsening respiratory status, including which of the following a) Low grade fever
options: Productive cough
Increased restlessness
Hoarse voice

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Danny shows signs of acute respiratory distress, and his mother brings him to the accident and emergency clinic. Which of the following changes in vital signs would the nurse expect to note a) Bradycardia, tachypnea
options: Bradycardia, bradypnea
Tachycardia, tachypnea
Tachycardia, bradypnea

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Ongoing assessment of danny includesregular oximetry readings. The reading changes to 75%. Your immediate reaction is to
options: Increase the level of oxygen being administered
Check the accuracy of the oximeter
Visually check the childs respiratory status
Go and get someone to check your recordings

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Dannys health improves, he is able to go home. His mother says i have used all my money to get the taxi here. I cannot get home. Your response is a) Thats okay, i’ll pay for thetaxi for you
options: You cant stay here, this is an emergency clinic
Can i ring someone else at home for you
You can use a credit card with the taxi

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Dannys mother bursts into tears. I don’t want to go home because my husbands drunk and he’ll beat me. Your response is
options: Would you like to talk about this in a quieter place
Shall we ring him to see if hes sober yet
I’ll contact a social worker for you
How often does he get drunk and beat you

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: At the time of leonards admission to hospital, it would be impossible to accurately predict the neurological deficit that would ultimately be left because
options: With correct alignment of the severed sections of cord, some healing of fibres will occur
Some of his symptoms may be the result of spinal shock rather than severance of the cord
If the cord has been severed cleanly, it may be possible to suture the tracts together
It is impossible for the spinal tracts to heal until the disrupted blood vessels supplying the cord regenerate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Reflex control over the bowel and bladder functions following spinal injury is expected to be regained. This control over evacuation may develop because
options: Initial bowel and bladder problems result more from psychological than from physical injury
Some of the severed motor fibres will reconnect, permitting impulse transmission
With mobilisation and improved circulation, muscle control will improve
Return of parasympathetic activity will permit automatic emptying of bladder and bowel

Application of r
restraints
Identification and social supports
Replacement of fluids and electrolytes

Salbutamol (ventolin) is administered through a nebuliser four hourly. The primary action of this drug is as a a) Bronchodilator

options: Set standards and determine criteria

options: An agreed upon base line condition or level of excellence
An evaluation instrumental tool used by all
A set of behaviours that are common and understood by all
A set of behaviours that are defined by others for a profession

options: The nurses clinical practice
The nursing care clients receive

The foetus presents by vertex

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Cultural safety to practice in nursing is best describe by all of the following except

Mental, physical and family kinship components

In a sensitive manner actively discourage any treatment or care strategy not congruent with the clients own beliefs

options: Use jargon free language
Check client understanding

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When assessing families or an individual within a cultural context the nurse in either a community or hospital setting needs to be aware of

options: Recognizing that the human experience of illness is identical to the biomedical interpretation of disease
Recognizing that many maori clients have their own concepts and interpretations about illness and health

What actions would you take in this situation

Inform the charge nurse, explaining what you overheard and leave it for her to deal with

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: weeks gestation

opportunity to learn to know other children more quickly
opportunity to reject the reality of the hospital

use cough suppressant only at bedtime

in the emergency care situation

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs todd is placed in a room with three other people, she asks ‘what is the matter with that person opposite me’ what should the nurse say a) She do not know

Venereal disease

A cervical infection

The best possible level of mobility and ambulation

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: While mr march is hospitalised, the nurse is concerned with preventing the complications of prolonged bed rest. Mr march already has a reddened area over the sacrum and coccyx. The nurse knows that the most important action to prevent a decubitus ulcer is to

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Peter has a temper tantrum during which he lies on the floor at the entrance to the hallway. This is making it difficult for other residents. He has been asked to get up but continues his tantrum. Using the principles of extinction how would you deal with peter

Ignore him and instruct the other residents to step over him

options: To be rewarded for inappropriate behaviour
To be punished for inappriate behaviour

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: If the staff were to apply the principles of response cost in dealing with peters inappropriate social behaviour they could do so by

When sean starts oral feeding it is particularly important that his client has a high amount of
