exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is essential in assisting the family to help peter to develop independence
options: Observe what he can and cannot do
Recognise his need to be treated as a normal adolescent
Stress that going away from home is a creative adventure
Gain an insight into the limitations imposed by his family circumstances

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Simon aged 14 years is paraplegic and has an athetoid type of cerebral palsy. He has been admitted to a psychopaedic assessment unit. Which of the following best describes athetoisis
options: Hypertonicity of head, neck and shoulder muscles
Voluntary writing or throwing movements of the whole body
Hypotonia and impairment of postural fixation of the trunk
Involuntary movements affecting almost all muscles of the body

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What characterises the muscle movement of athetosis
options: Abnormal reflex activity
Exacerbated by attempts at intentional movement
Exaggerated spasticity in movement
Slow, writhing, continous involuntary movements

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: All of the following may be the cause of chronic constipation except
options: Very refined food
Too much fibre in the diet
Too little fluid in the diet
Poor muscle tone in the bowel

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is the best combination of foods to help relieve constipation
options: Raw fruit and vegetables
Cooked meat and raw vegetables
Cooked fruit and refined cereals
Refined cereals and well cooked vegetables

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: How are passive exercises undertaken
options: Without the persons active assistance
Without any help from the physiotherapist
Only with assistance from the physiotherapist
By the use of weights to strengthen the muscles

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Why is joint movement promoted in simons physiotherapy programme
options: Prevents contractures of his muscles
Stimulates voluntary muscular movements
Maintains circumduction of the hip joint
Maintains the strength of his leg muscles

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which action is most likely to prevent the formation of a bed sore
options: Changing the position every two hours
Placing a sheepskin under the buttocks
Placing a rubber ring under the buttocks
Vigorously massage the area with silicone cream

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The most helpful measure to assist a 14 year old boy with paraplegia and cerebral palsy to cope with urinary incontinence is to a) Offer a urinal at regular intervals
options: Keep a disposable urinal in place at all times
Teach him to use a penile appliance and self emptying bag
Insert a retention catheter to prevent overdistension of the bladder

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which urinary tract problem is most likely to occur as a complication of immobility
options: Haematuria and infection
Stress, incontinence and infection
Renal calculi and infection
Bladder distension and haematuria

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Bruce, aged 15 years has had a moderate intellectual disability from infancy. He has recently moved into a hostel and attends a special school where his behaviour is reported to be both antisocial and disruptive. What is the most likely reason or bruces recently reported behaviour problem
options: He has no single set of ideals on which he can depend
He is concerned about what may happen next to him
His thoughts about being independent have caused an identity crises
He needs to regain a feeling of security and confidence he felt when he lived at home

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The most effective behaviour therapy in bruces situation would be to
options: Punish him so that disruptive tendencies are eliminated
Develop a reliable behaviour pattern for effective social functioning
Arrange contingencies between his behaviour and its long term consequences
Manipulate the environmental factors to make acceptable behaviour highly probable

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What is the most important reason for keeping records during bruces behaviour therapy programme
options: Provide a primary source of baseline information
Provide evidence of programmes that achieve their desired effect
Limit personal biases when his behavioural programme is discussed
Provide some objective method for evaluating the outcome of the techniques used

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following should be undertaken first when planning a behaviour therapy programme for bruce
options: Consulting his relatives
Assessing his present level of functioning
Deciding on the overall goals for his programme
Arranging with the psychologist for psychological testing

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When introducing bruce to a reward schedule it is best to
options: Make sure bruce feels he never gets enough of the reward
Use a strong reward for target behaviour every time it happens
Use the chosen schedule until his behaviour is completely controlled
Use an intermittent schedule until bruce understands what is expected of him

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following applies when changing bruce from a continuous to an intermittent behaviour schedule
options: Explain to him what is happening
Reduce the number of rewards slowly
Use only natural rewards for target behaviour
Continue to reward target behaviour each time it occurs

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The primary principle in preparing a new teaching programme for bruce is to
options: Prevent him repeating mistakes
Use and extend his current learning achievements
Assist him to achieve a satisfactory quality of life
Offer encouragement for socially appropriate behaviour

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Prescribed is heparin 125000 units. The vial you have contains heparin 1 mega unit in 2mls. What is the correct dose a) 0.025 mls
options: 0.25 mls
0.5 mls
1.0 ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The doctor orders 1000 mls of barts to be infused over 8 hours. The drip factor is 15. What is the number of drops per minute a) 3
Penicillin 250 mgs is prescribed. The drug available in powdered form is reconstituted to contain 600 mg in 2 ml. what amount should be given a) 0.75 ml
options: 0.8 ml
0.9 ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Under the misuse of drugs act 1975, a registered nurse may be convicted in a criminal court of law for
options: Giving prescribed sedation to a patient in hospital
Possessing a controlled drug, not prescribed for the nurse by a medical practitioner
Signing the controlled drug register, having given a prescribed medication
Refusing to give a prescribed controlled drug to a patient suffering from chronic pain

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The preliminary precaution that must be observed first before the nurse gives the ampule of medication handed to her by the charge nurse is to a) Wash her hands
options: Sight the doctors prescription
Check the charge nurse gives the orders in writing
Check the prescription is writing in duplicate on the patients chart

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: kg, has disturbed sleep patterns and has very little energy. She is admitted to hospital with a diagnosis of depression. What other feature is she likely to demonstrate on admission a) Flight of ideas
options: Halluscinations
Feelings of persecution
Feelings of worthlessness

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The most important priority in your assessment would be to gain information concerning which of the following a) Unresolved conflicts
options: Ideas of self harm
Current stresses
Previous history

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs carr tells you she would like to go to sleep and never wake up. Which response is the most appropriate
options: Lets go for a walk to cheer you up
Youll feel better in a day or so
Are you saying you want to die
Your medication will make you feel differently

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs carr is assessed as being actively suicidal and has refused all food and fluids since admission this morning. Choose the most appropriate group of nursing interventions
options: Nutrition, psychotherapy and medication
Constant observation, supportive care and nutrition
Supervised activity, nutrition and family visits
Constant observation nutrition and medication

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs carr is given tricyclic anti depressant medication. After four days she tells you that the pills are not working. Choose the most appropriate action a) Report her statement to the house surgeon
options: Tell mrs carr that the medication will take at least 10 days to start working
Discuss mrs carrs anxieties about medication with her
Record her statement in the nursing records

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs carr asks you how long she will have to take medication. Your most appropriate response would be
options: The medication takes a maximum of four weeks to be fully effective
Usually people continue on this type of medicine all their lives
Once your condition improves your medication may be gradually reduced
The maximum time on this type of medication is six to twelve months

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs carr complains of a dry mouth. The most likely reason for this is
options: Insufficient fluids
Anxiety
Side effects of medication
Nervous system response

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Four weeks later mrs carr is granted weekend leave. She tells you she has a bottle of anti depressants at home, which she will take if things do not go well. Your response would be to
options: Tell her that the responsibility is hers
Listen and report to the team so that her leave can be reconsidered
Make a contract with her that she will not harm herself
Reassure her that she is much improved and will cope with leave

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The physician orders a different type of medication when mrs carr does not respond positively to a tricyclic anti depressant. While the patient is taking the newly prescribed drug, tranylcyclopromine sulphate (parnate), which one of the following reactions is likely to occur if the patients diet includes foods containing tyramine a) Heart block
options: Grand mal seizure
Hypertensive crises
Renal failure

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs carr again obtains permission for leave. Which one of the following preparations by her husband indicates the best understanding of the her needs a) Planning to involve her in their usual at home pursuits
options: Bringing her bed downstairs so she can rest during the day
Scheduling a day of interesting activites outside of the home
Arranging for a friend of the family to watch her at all times

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs carr has learnt that practicing relaxation gives her a feeling of control over her depressing thoughts. The particular part of the nervous system activated through relaxation training is the
options: Sympathetic nervous system
Parasympathetic nervous system
Central nervous system
Peripheral vasoconstriction

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Eric smythe, a 45 year old non maori man is admitted as an informal patient the psychiatric unit after a week in intensive care following an over dose of imipramine. He had been on this medication for depression for the preceding twelve months. During the interview, you as the admitting nurse, observe that no longer appears depressed, is somewhat detached and is joking about his foolishness (referring to his suicide attempt). Eric requests discharge, stating that he is afraid to lose any more time off work and that his family will not cope if he doesn’t go home now. From the interview data you assume that
options: Eric has gained insight into his self destructive behaviour
Eric desire to return to work and his family indicates good judgement
Erics affect indicates that his bout of depression is now over
Erics comments may indicate he is suicidal and is trying to bide it

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Establishing a therapeutic relationship with eric will contribute to which of the following
options: The feeling that he is worthless
The feeling that others pressure him
The feeling that he is overprotected
The feeling that others want him to live

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: One day when erics wife visits she finds him quietly weeping and saying he cant go on. She asks you to calm him down. Your best response would be a) All right, ill talk to him and see if I can find out whats wrong
options: If you just sit quietly with him, im sure hell calm down
Its hard to see him so upset, but he needs to let the feelings out
We can both stay with him until he has regained control if you like

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: One of the things that the nurse must be aware of when caring for eric as he recovers from depression is
options: He is considered less of a suicide risk than when severly depressed
He is no longer considered a suicide risk as he recovers
He is considered more of a suicide risk when he is recovering
He is considered more of a suicide risk when in the depths of depression

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: While on leave eric again takes an overdose of his antidepressants. He rings the ward to let you know he will not be back and tells you why. What approach will you take in this situation
options: Keep him on the phone and send the police to bring him to hospital
Persuade him to put his wife on the phone and ask her to bring him to hospital
Convince him to drive himself back to the hospital to get treatment
Look up his address go out and bring him to hospital yourself

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The team decide that erics condition is serious. They decide he should undergo a course of E.C.T. before his first treatment at 8am, you should be sure eric has a) Has recently urinated
options: Has not drunk for 12 hours
Signed a consent form
Has not eaten for 12 hours
All of the above

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs smythe asks you what to expect when she visits eric after his treatment, which of the following is the most accurate information
options: It is possible that he may not recognise you for a few days
There will probably be a temporary and expected loss of memory
He will be so confused that it will be best not to visit today
He will be very sleepy and unable to tolerate a long visit

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Eric makes good progress with E.C.T and antidepressant therapy and is ready for discharge. He asks you what signs to look out for in the future that might indicate a recurrence of depression. Your best response is
options: Grandiosity, insomnia, self devaluation, psychomotor retardation
Persecution, insomnia, self devaluation, psychomotor retardation
Paranoia, insomnia, self devaluation, psychomotor retardation
Withdrawal, insomnia, self devaluation, psychomotor retardation

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are working the evening shift in the intensive care unit. You observe that there are times when patients appear not to respond to injections of diazepam (valium). On further investigation you discover that the lack of response occurs ofter the medication has been administered by mrs H, a day shift nurse. One evening mrs H is assigned to work with you on the evening shift because one of the regular staff is absent. After dinner you observe that one of the patients received diazepam but is still anxious. You also observe that mrs H appears slightly euphoric, uncoordinated, and her speech is slurred. The first action for you to take is
options: Arrange to observe mrs h when she prepared medications
Ask other nurses if they have observed anything unusual
Call the nursing supervisor and ask her to confront mrs h with you
Tell mrs h that you know she has been stealing drugs

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What distinguishes substance dependence from substance abuse
options: Tolerance for the substance and psychological dependency
Tolerance for the substance and polydrug abuse
Tolerance for the substance and withdrawal reactions
Psychological dependency and withdrawal reactions

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: It is determined that mrs h has a drug abuse problem. A positive initial intervention would be
options: Dismissal from her job
Referral to a self help group
Counselling by the head nurse
Referral to a drug treatment programme

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When withdrawing the client from benzodiazepines the most important thing to remember is
options: To get the client off the substance as quickly as possible
To perform an accurate assessment and establish a baseline before proceeding
To get the client off the substance slowly
To educate them re other problem solving techniques

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following groups of responses is characteristic of addiction to antianxiety agents
options: Psychological addiction, tolerance no physical addiction
Physical addiction, tolerance, no psychological addiction
Psychological addiction, no physical addiction, no tolerance
Physical addiction, psychological addiction, tolerance

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr D B brown a 45 year old non maori man is admitted to the ward in which you are working following a domestic dispute, during which time he smashed the family home up and punched his fist through a window, causing severe lacerations of his hand, for which he has received treatment. It is suspected that a drinking problem has played a major part in his presentation. This may be confirmed by his developing early signs of withdrawal which would include
options: Anxious, restless, and perspiring profusely
Presenting as undernourished and unsteady on his feet
Confused and disorientated
Denying vehemently that he has a drinking problem

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Generally, the long term course of alcoholism
options: Follows a common progression in different people
Differs between men and women but is the same within the sexes
Shows that blockouts after modest drinking are a valid early indicator of alcoholism
Is highly variable for each individual

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: How can it be that alcohol consumption is initiated to reduce distress, if most of its effects are negative
options: Denial of the negative effects keeps drinkers as seeing them as a punishment
The negative effects are transient and weak, while the positive effects are powerful and long lasting
People who start to drink have a diminished capacity to learn from experience
Negative effects of alcohol consumption are relatively remote, while positive effects are immediate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: One night when mr browns wife does visit, after two weeks, she asks to speak you privately and tells you that her husband has asked her to come home again. She wonders whether this is just another ploy, or should she give the marriage another go. Would you
options: Advise her that alcoholics lie and deceive, and can never change
Tell her that marriage is for better or worse and that the most appropriate thing to do is for them to get back together again
Advise her to get professional help for herself, in order to work out her immediate priorities, preferably from an alcohol related agency
Tell her that shes best out of it; suggest terminating as its only like to happen again

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Co dependent people would be best served from a therapeutic point of view in
options: Helping their partner get help
Getting out of the situation before they get physically hurt
Looking at the damage the dependency has caused them
Finding out why they always end up with a loser

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Kate elliot, a 38 year old non maori woman, is admitted to hospital. She shares a flat with her long time friend edith. Edith tells you that kate has recently become over active and upset and claims that her butcher and local supermarket are both trying to poison her. The newspaper is printing lies about her past and she has started a few fires in their garden recently in an attempt to burn the newspaper. She is unable to sleep at night and is always finding things to do. Last night she was vacuum cleaning the flat at 3 am. Kate is unable to add any information as she switches topics so rapidly she does not make sense. Which of the following is the best description of the reason for kates admission
options: She is creating a disturbance
She is frightened of being poisoned
She is a danger to herself and others
She has no one to look after her

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is a priority for kates care on admission
options: Distract her from unrealistic thoughts
Orient her to reality
Alleviate her anxiety
Introduce her to others

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: To assist kate to regain self control she is given an intramuscular injection of ahlorpromazine 100mg. following the injection her blood pressure is likely to be a) Much higher than before
options: Moderately higher than before
About he same as before
Marginally lower than before

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Kates mood settles and she says she feels her old self except for dizziness when she stands up. Which of the following responses would you choose
options: It is nothing to worry about, just try to straighten up more slowly in future
Its quite normal at your age, especially if you bend with straight knees
You medicine has many side effects and dizziness is one of them
Sit down in your chair and ill check your blood pressure

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Kate continues to complain of dizziness and says she feels nauseous most of the time. Which of the following signs would lead you to suspect lithium toxicity a) Weight gain, staggering, thirst
options: Weight gain, hypertension thirst
Vomiting, thirst, hypertension
Vomiting, coarse tremor, staggering

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In the client with an elevated mood there is often difficulty with diet because they
options: Feel unworthy of food
Are preoccupited with trivialities
Do not slow down long enough to eat
Think the food is poisoned

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: John, aged 18 years, has been a patient in a psychiatric unit for three days. He was brought in for 5 day compulsory assessment in response to his self destructive behaviour and his threats to harm others. On admission he is mistrustful and is experiencing hallucinations. He has had one previous admission when he was diagnosed as having schizophrenia. While communicating with john, the nurse should
options: Remain silent with him and not encourage him to verbalise
Talk with john as she would a normal person
Allow john to do all the talking
Use simple concrete language when talking to john

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Schizophrenia is often characterised by a lack of insight. This refers to
options: Poor social skills
Superficiality
Failure to recognize that they are suffering from anemotional disorder
Difficulty in reading other peoples motives

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: John is taking chlorpromazine 100mg q.i.d. after 4 days he is unable to sit for any length of time, fidgets a lot, and tends to wander around the unit. Which side effect is he exhibiting a) Dystonia
options: Akathisia
Parasthemia
Dyskinesia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: John refuses his antipsychotic tablets because he thinks he is getting too drowsy. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial nursing action a) Offer it in an alternative form
options: Discuss with him the consequences of refusing
Accept his refusal and record this
Crush the tablets and add them to his food

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The four ‘A”s of schizophrenia are
options: Association, ambivalence, alienation and autism
Ambivalence, autism, affect and association
Affect, ambivalence, assimilation, and autism
Affect, accommodation, autism and ambivalence

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is not a typical sign of early epatitis
options: Ascites
Slightly yellowing of the sclera
Clay stools
Anorexia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: During the infectious stage, a person with hepatitis A is excreting the virus mainly in
options: Faeces
Urine
Saliva
All body fluids

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When a person is in the infectious stage of hepatitis A, special precautions are taken when you
options: Take a food tray to the person
Administer medications
Gave an antiemetic injection
Remove a used bedpan

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Client has been back from surgery for several hours and has not asked for pain medication. The client and nurse are from different cultural groups. Being aware of cultural influences on health behaviours, the nurse will
options: Realise the client probably does not feel as much pain as some people
Wait for the client to ask before bringing pain medication
Look for non verbal signs of pain, such as holding the incision or lying still
Tell the client to be sure to call her if he/she is in pain

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Although the home health nurse has taught the client the importance of taking his antibiotic exactly every six hours, he still cannot seem to take it on schedule. In evaluating the facts of her teaching, the holistic nurse should consider that the client (who is from a different culture) possibly
options: Is relating to time differently than she
Has not understood what she taught
Does not believe the medicine will help
All of above

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Smoking is bad for people with chronic respiratory disorders because cigarette smoke
options: Destroys the cilia which cleanse debris from the airways
Inhibits the inspiratory centres in the central nervous system
Inhibit nerves involved in the reflex pathways involved in coughing
Prevents the vocal cords closing tightly together when swallowing

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: One reason why smokers with chronic respiratory problems should not be given medications that inhibit the cough reflex is
options: These medications dry up mucus and make secretions difficult to expel
The hypoxic drive is inhibited causing a slowing in breathing rate
Coughing is their only means of preventing mucous accumulating in the lungs
In people with chronic problems these medications have no effect anyway

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Asthma is a disorder primarily characterised by
options: Hyperinflation and over expansion of lung tissue
Spastic constriction of the respiratory airways
A breakdown in the walls of alveolar tissue
Chronic dilation and expansion of the airways

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: During acute asthmatic attacks theophylline medications are given because they
options: Stimulate the inspiratory centre
Raise the blood PO2 levels
Hyperinflate the lung
Dilate the bronchioles

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Aminophylline comes in ampoules of 250 mgs in 10 mls. How much in mls, would you draw up to obtain 300 mgs a) 8.3
In the early stages of obstruction to urine flow, symtoms which a client with an enlarged prostate gland might experience include
options: Difficulty in emptying his bladder and hematuria
Foul smelling urine with a high bacteria count
Complete retention of urine and dribbling
Frequency, urgency, a poor stream and nocturia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A client is prescribed 1 litre of dextrose/saline to be given over 3 hours. If the I>V giving set has a drop factor of 15 drops per ml, which of the following, in drops per minute, gives the correct rate a) 17
Your client states that she is most unhappy with the care she is receiving from her doctor and wishes to change doctors. You respond
options: Would you like to talk to me about why you are unhappy with your care – I may be able to help
Okay – should be no problem, its your choice after all
I don’t think that’s a good idea – it can lead to the doctor becoming annoyed
Hospital policy does not allow for you to make a choice of doctor but would you like to talk to me about your concerns

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Johnny is 22 years old and has been admitted under section 8 of the mental health act (1992). Period of assessment of Johnny is for a) 14 days
options: 6 months
7 days
5 days

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In an acute presentation, such as Johnny, the need to administer medication so as to address the situation is important. The most likely choice of drug would be a) Trifluoperazine
options: Thioridiazine
Haloperidol decanoate
Benzotropine mesylate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When administering this medication what is the dosage and upper limit or ceiling in a twenty four hour period
options: 2mgs, up to 6mgs/24hrs
6mgs, up to 12mgs/24hrs
20mgs, up to 60mgs/24hrs
4mgs, up to 12mgs/24hrs

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Following this episode, Johnny is commenced on a regular anticholinergic antiparkinsonian drug. The most likely drug of choice would be a) Procyclidine
options: Lorazepam
Pipothiazine
Diazepam

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Johnny is charted this medication. Which of the following drug orders reflects the amount/dosage to be received accurately a) 5mgs TDS
options: 20mgs nocte
10mgs QQII
15mgs mane and 15mgs nocte

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Johnny responds well to her care and is discharged 14 days later. He is charted an antipsychotic injectable medication which the mental health nurse gives her at home. The medication is flupenthixol deconoate. The dosage and frequency is likely to be a) 400mgs every 3 weeks
options: 150mgs every week
60mgs every 3 weeks
200 mgs every 2 weeks

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Tom has a diagnosis of bipolar affective disorder and his family ask you to talk with them about it. They ask you what an affective disorder is. The therapeutic response would be
options: An abnormality in the mood or feeling state of a person
A dysfunctional emotive illness exacerbated intermittently
A chronic and progressive deterioration in the emotion of a person
A strange feeling which is abnormal in origin

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Tom is admitted to the unit where you work. You are concerned in your assessment to ensure he is physically well. Your care plan would include therefore, a focus on a) Rest and sleep, fluid and nutritional needs, elimination and personal safety
options: Relationship needs, diet and exercise, and group therapy
Counselling needs, altered thought processes and orientation
Food and fluids, lowered mood and poor communication

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Toms family asks you why he must take the big white tablets. They say they taste like chalk and that he only needs them when he is sick. A therapeutic response would be
options: I can understand how it seems that way but he tablets work best when they are taken all the time
That’s why he is sick because he should have been taking them
You ought to be encouraging him to take them all the time
Yes, perhaps encourage him to take them just when he needs to

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Tom is due for a test today and the lab technicians arrive to do the blood test. Tom asks you what the level needed in his blood is. A correct response is a) 1.5 – 2meg
Toms level comes back from the lab who ring you to tell you that his level is very high. The immediate nursing actions would involve
options: A check to see if a.m dose was given, discontinue meds and notify doctor
Commencement on fluid balance chart and vital recordings
Encourage fluid intake and continue meds and document observations
Inform tom he is toxic, place on bedrest and notify next of kin

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Tom is assessed and has lithium toxicity. The symptoms we would expect to see as nurses are
options: Palpitations, skin rash and headache
Potophobia, bradycardia and dyspnoea
Coarse tremor, diarrhoea, vomiting and sluggishness
Thirst, nausea, skin rash and pain on dorsal flexion

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are a domicillary nurse and have been visiting liz in the community. Liz is receiving an antipsychotic in infectable form. Which medication is not an injectable antipsychotic
options: Pipothiazine
Thioridiazine
Haldol decanoate
Flupenthixol

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Before liz was commenced on her medication you asked that she be charted a test dose. This lower dose is
options: Given then received after 5 days before regular charting begins
Given fortnightly for a period of six months
Administered and then followed immediately by a regular dose if no reaction is noted
Administered once and then repeated weekly for four weeks

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Liz continues to request that her injection site be in her buttock and refuses to have it in the thigh. You have permission to do this. You assure the accurate site by a) Locating the upper, outer quadrant of the buttock
options: Locating the lower, outer quadrant of the buttock
Locating the iliac crest and administering the injection
Locating the midline and injecting 3cms to the side of it

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In regularly dispensing injectable medication you are aware as a nurse that the medication is locally irritating. You therefore a) Administer it in one area only
options: Rub the area gently following administration
Rotate sites and do not rub/massage the area
Apply heat and massage the area

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jan is a first line manager responsible for the care of a group of patients. She is concerned because for the last three weeks the physiotherapist has been late to see the patients and sometimes has not come at all. She has called the physiotherapist but the situation has not improved. Jans next action should be to a) Write a memo to the physiotherapy department
options: Contact a nursing clinical advisor
Notify the physician of the situation
Consult her nurse manager

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In organisations the primary management function is to
options: Assess and establish goals
Establish a framework in which to function
Plan for results
Control all operations

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Cohesiveness is important to all teams. This means
options: The process a group goes through in deciding what to do
A mutual attraction which holds a group together
A decision made by a knowledgeable leader for the group
A strong organisational support system of the group

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Part of jans position requires her to manage the budget. This is
options: A statement of future expenditures
A list of current expenditure
A plan for meeting expenses
A recording of past expenditure

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jan is aware that nursing tasks and quality of nursing practice are compared with which pivotal question
options: Does the performance match standards and objectives
Does the performance reflect interest and enthusiasm for the job
Does performance indicate knowledge and expertise
Does performance leave the patients comfortable

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Elanor brown aged 20 is a passenger who is thrown clear when the car she is travelling in hits a lamp post. Eleanor exhibits internal bleeding later diagnosed a ruptured spleen. First aid care for Eleanor includes elevating her limbs. This is done to a) Decrease her venous return
options: Lower her blood pressure
Increase her venous return
Assist her to breathe

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Eleanor is admitted to the accident and emergency department in advanced stage 2 shock. When taking her base line observations you would expect to find a) Elevated BP, elevated pulse rate and elevated respiratory rate
options: Decreased BP, decreased pulse rate and decreased respiratory rate
Decreased BP, increased pulse rate and increased respiratory rate
Decreased BP, decreased pulse rate and increased respiratory rate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are a community nurse working with families who have lost a child to sudden infant death syndrome. A parent says ‘sally was so healthy I just cant understand what would have caused this. Where did we go wrong’. What is the most appropriate response
options: I don’t know why you feel responsible for what happened to sally
Try not to blame yourself for sallys death
You didn’t no one knows the cause of S.I.D.S
Did sally seem sick before bedtime

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The primary etiology of S.I.D.S is
options: Cardiac arrhythmias
Unknown
Depression of respirations
Exhaustion

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Sudden infant death syndrome often occurs
options: Between 2-6 months following birth
Within 3 weeks of birth
More than 6 months after birth
Between 9-12 months of age

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Babies who die from sudden infant death syndrome/S.I.D.S are more frequently
options: Low birthweight babies
Born to a mother over 40
From middle class families
From families with a history of s.I.D.S

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Research has indicated that the best way to try to reduce the incidence of sudden infant death syndrome is
options: Feeding baby four hourly
Having baby sleeping on their back
Wrapping baby up firmly
Sleeping prone

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A family have already had one child die from SIDS. They are offered an apnoea monitor for their new baby. To assist this family you should begin by a) Teaching cardiopulmonary resuscitation
options: Teaching use of monitoring equipment including safety precautions
Creating an opportunity for parents to discuss their feeling and concerns
Referring to an appropriate support group in the community

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Items relate to congenital defects in children. A positive diagnostic test for cystic fibrosis is
options: Sweat analysis
Sputum analysis
Liver function test
Bone marrow biopsy

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The earliest recongnizable clinical manifestations of cystic fibrosis is
options: Foul smelling, frothy, greasy stools
Recurrent pneumonia and lung infections
Meconium ileus
History of poor intestinal absorption

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In providing nourishment for a child with cystic fibrosis, which of the following factors should the nurse keep in mind
options: Most fruits and vegetables are not well tolerated
Diet should be high in carbohydrates and protein
Diet should be high in easily digested carbohydrates and fats
Fats and proteins must be greatly curtailed

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which statement expresses accurately the genetic implications of cystic fibrosis
options: If it is present in a child both parents are carriers of this defective gene
It is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait
It is a genetic defect found primarily in non white population groups
There is a 50% chance that siblings of an affected child will also be affected

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following statements best describes hirschsprung disease
options: It is a disease characterized by the absence of parasympathetic ganglion cells in a segment of the colon
It is a disease that results in excessive peristaltic movements within the gastrointestinal tract
It is a disease that results in frequent evaculation of solids, liquids, and gas
It is often diagnosed in newborns when they fail to pass the transitional stool within 24 hours after birth

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Congential defects of the genitourinary tract such as hypospadias are usually repaired as early as possible to
options: Prevent mental illness
Prevent separation anxiety
Promote acceptance of hospitalization
Promote development of normal body image

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Hypospadias refers to which of the following
options: Urethral opening along dorsal surface of penis
Urethral opening along ventral surface of penis
Absence of an urethral opening
Penis shorter than usual for age

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Foetal alcohol syndrome results when the
options: Mother is an alcoholic
Mother drinks excessively during the first trimester
Alcohol consumed by the mother is in excess of the brains ability to detoxify
Alcohol consumed by the mother is in excess of the livers ability to detoxify

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The doctor observed a child with phloric stenosis closely during feeding periods. Which of the following observations made of the exposed abdomen is most indicative of pyloric stenosis
options: Abdominal rigidity
Substernal retraction
Visible peristalsis
Marked distention

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The presence of the Mongolian blue spot
options: 1 and 2
1 and 3
1, 2 and 4
1, 2 and 3

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are asked about the incidence of downs syndrome. The incidence/1000 live births is greatest when the maternal age is a) Under 16 years
options: 16-20 years
21-40 years
Over 40 years

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The genetic defect which causes downs syndrome is mostly due to Trisomy Meiosis Mutation Mitosis Sophie one day old was born with a hernia protrusion of a sac li?? Cyst of meninges, spinal fluid and a portion of the spinal cord with its nerves through a defect in the vertebral column. This defect in the vertebral column is called
options: Hydrocephalus
Encephalocele
Meningocele
Meningomyelocele

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are sophies primary nurse in the special care baby unit. When her father visits for the first time, he is most likely to exhibit which reaction a) Anger
options: Depression
Disbelief
Bargaining

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Some children with spina bifida show spinal deformities at birth or develop them during growth after birth eg kyphosis which is
options: The spine bends sideways and also rotates on a vertical axis – often a rib hump is present
The lumbar spine bows inwards
A lateral curve of the spine
The spine bows backwards and resembles the letter c when viewed from the side in a sitting position

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Sophie’s head measurements are of concern. The doctor diagnoses hydrocephalus. This is most accurately defined as
options: Greatly increased head diameter due to spreading of the sutures by massive cerebral oedema
Progressive enlargement of the head due to excessive accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid
Elevation of the dome of the skull by a haematoma secondary to skull fracture
Distention of the frontal, maxillary and ethnoid sinuses with inflammatory exudates

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Administer oxygen via a mask at 6 litres per minute
options: 2, 3 and 4
2, 3 and 5

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Six glycerol trinitrate tablets prior to admission
options: 3, 4 and 5
2, 3 and 4
1, 4 and 5
1, 2 and 4

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The main therapeutic action of IV morphine given to a client following a myocardial infarction is to
options: Relax the client and allow him/her to sleep
Relieve pain and to help prevent severe shock
Relieve acute level of anxiety
Relieve pain and stimulate respiratory function

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The occupation health nurse observes a sucking chest wound in the right wall of Harvey, a man who has been involved in an industrial accident. The initial action by the nurse should be to
options: Immediately cover the wound with anything available
Assess the chest for asymmetry
Obtain a sterile petroleum gauze dressing
Place Harvey in an upright position

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: To facilitate lung expansion, the nurse should encourage Harvey to breath in which manner
options: Shallowly, through the nose
Inhale deeply, then exhale with the mouth and nose closed
Inhale normally, breathe out through pursed lips
Breathe as normally as possible

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following type of crises is Harvey experiencing
options: Developmental crises
Adventitious crises
Situational crises
Maturational crises

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Later, the occupational health nurse is asked to give a session on chest injuries. The most important pre crises emphasis would be a) Accident prevention
options: Chest assessment
Pathophysiology of chest injuries
Rapid treatment techniques

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Percy a 55 year old is suffering from parkinsons disease. You are administering anti parkinsons drugs. Which of the following would increase their absorption a) Marmite sandwich
options: Glass of milk
Glass of water
Plain biscuit

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following are symptoms of parkinsons disease
options: Speech disturbance, confusion
Muscle rigidity, tremors
Weak arms, difficulty in swallowing
Depression, hemianopia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Percy often has difficulty maintaining balance while ambulating. The most helpful intervention to prevent him falling would be a) Instruct him to wear elastic stockings
options: Instruct him to use wide based stance
Teach him how to perform range of motion exercises
Instruct him to change position slowly

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Patricia wakes up one morning with a severe headache. While attempting to get up to take some aspirin she collapses. Her husband sends for the doctor, who, suspecting a cerebrovascular accident arranges hospitalisation. On admission patricia is comatosed. All the following can be used when assessing a patients level of consciousness except a) Degree of orientation to surroundings
options: Reaction of the pupils to light
Reaction to painful stimuli
Ability to obey commands

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Ann a student nurse, is playing tennis after duty when she is stung by a bee. Her friends recognise signs of systemic anaphylaxis and immediately take her to the emergency department. The signs and symptoms of systemic anaphylaxis include dyspnoea and which of the following a) Facial oedema, hypotension
options: Facial oedema, hypertension
Polyuria, hypotension
Polyuria, hypertension

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The most effective drug in the immediate treatment of anaphylactic shock is a) Penicillin
options: Solu-medrol
Benadryl
Adrenalin

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs green 29 years old, is admitted with acute abdominal pain, vomiting and suspected peritonitis. After admission mrs green is on nil per mouth in anticipation of early
options: Diagnosis
X-ray
Ultrasound scan
Surgery

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs green returns from theatre following an appendectomy. Your immediate nursing response would be to assess a) Wound site
options: Intravenous line
Heart rate
Airway

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs green is ordered intravenous normal saline 1000ml over 8 hours. You have a metriset in situ (drop factor =60). How many drops per minute will you be monitoring this at a) 21
Mrs green develops a paralytic ileus. Which of the following is almost always an indication of paralytic ileus a) Alteration in vital signs
options: Increasing abdominal distension
Persistent vomiting
Absence of bowel motions

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs green is ordered amoxicillin 1.2gm. on hand are 500 mgm vials, each to be dissolved in 2ml of sterile water. How much will you give a) 2.4ml
options: 3.6ml
4.8ml
5.2ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: On the third day of hospitalisation a patient informs the nurse that she would rather bathe at night. To best promote continuity of care the nurse should a) Explain the am care is given in the morning
options: Verbally inform the other health team members
Indicate this preference on the nursing care plan
Encourage her to modify her routine while hospitalised

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: After a month in the hospital a jewish patient says she misses lightening her candles on Friday night (shabbas licht). The most therapeutic response would be a) It must be difficult to change old habits
options: Religious traditions have a peaceful effect
I am sorry but that’s against the fire code
I will try to arrange it so you can light your candles

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs hill is charted nitrazepam (mogadon) tablets to sleep. She refuses to take them at 9pm. She tells you that the other nurses always leave the tablets on the locker and she takes them when she is ready. What should you do a) Put them back in the container
options: Give her the tablets and let her take them later
Tell the patient to ring when she is ready for them
Tell her if she doesn’t take them now she may not get them later

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Hyperventilation may initially cause
options: Metabolic acidosis
Metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory acidosis
Respiratory alkalosis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Without describing to them what is involved, the surgeon asks for consent for surgery from ivans parents. What is your responsibility in this situation a) Ensure the parents have been given appropriate information
options: Question the validity of this consent
Ensure the consent form is completed
Check whether the parents have any questions about the surgery

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Ivan is prescribed pethidine 75mg intramuscularly as a premedication. The drug is available in ampoules containing 100mg in 2ml. what dosage should be administered a) 0.75ml
options: 1.5ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which group of observations would the nurse make when checking the limb for vascular occlusion after the application of a plaster cast to limb a) Heat, burning, loss of feeling, immobility
options: Loss of function, redness, swelling, pain
Coldness, stiffness, odour, loss of feeling
Coldness, impairment of function, swelling, discolouration

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A reporter from a local paper phones the ward and asks for information on ivans condition. What is the appropriate response in this circumstance a) Ivan has a broken leg but is comfortable
options: Ill go and get the senior nurse on duty who will assist you with your queries
I cannot give you any information
Please contact the senior medical adviser for such information

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse is working in a psychiatric hospital. Susan aged 22 years is a lab technician who has a long history of compulsive food avoidance and a desire to be thin. Susan looks wasted and has pitted ankle edema. Height 162cm, weight 32kg. she is prescribed rest and a diet high in protein and calories. What is the most likely psychiatric diagnosis for susan a) Anorexia nervosa
options: Myasthenia gravis
Neurotic depression
Acute psychotic disorder

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Denial is an important part of susans behaviour. Which of the following intervensions is most therapeutic at the start of her care a) Confronting her with her problem of weight loss
options: Discussing the issue of her work related problems
Discussing the concept of slimness in relation to obesity
Attempting to establish rapport by discussing her interests

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Susan is dehydrated. The doctor orders 500ml normal saline Iv over 2 hours. The administration set delivers 15 drops per ml. what is the correct number of drops to be administered per minute a) 44

The nurse checks the drugs with a colleague who says, im not sleeping well, how about checking out a couple of mogadon for me to take home. Which is the appropriate response by the nurse a) Refuse, but offer panadeine
options: Discuss the reason why she cannot oblige
Encourage her to talk about her sleeplessness
Report the matter to the manager for advice

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A nurse who is concerned that a patient is being treated harshly by one of the visiting psychiatrists should first a) Tell the charge nurse
options: Inform the senior medical officer
Inform the patients relatives of the problem
Discuss the problem with the psychiatrist concerned

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When caring for a client in a drugged state, the nurse is often faced with verbal abuse. The nurse should handle this abuse by a) Insulting the client since it is deserved
options: Making a neutral response to the client
Refusing to provide care for the client
Ignoring the client and leaving the room

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Social policy makers have argued that maori health has suffered greatly because of inappropriate health service delivery. This can be attributed to a) Provision of a totally monocultural western type health care system
options: Lack of government health functioning
Low number of maori health providers
Maori urban migration

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which is the most appropriate response by the nurse making her first home visit to a newborn baby and mother when she learns from a neighbour that the mother and baby are at tangi on the local marae a) Leave a note to say she called
options: Leave a message with the neighbour
Visit the marae in search of mother and baby
Wait for the mother and baby to return from the tangi
Leave a note with your phone number and date of next visit

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In hauora the 1988 report which considered maori health standards, the leading cause of maori infant deaths was identified as a) Gastroenteritis
options: Middle and inner ear infections
Meningitis
Sudden infant death syndrome

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The report also found the maori have relatively high rates of physical and mental ill health. According to the report, the main reason for this is that they
options: Prefer to consult a tohunga regarding any health problem
Generally have poorer nutrition and stress management skills
Put family interests before the needs of the individual
Are more likely to be unemployed or have low earning capacity
Are disadvantaged socially, economically and culturally

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs latu, a tongan, is being admitted in the late first state of labour. She tells the nurse her husband is, ‘in the waiting room’. Which is the most appropriate response a) Would you like me to bring your husband in now
options: Would you like to have your husband present at delivery
It would be good for your husband to be with you when baby is born
Do you know it helps a father bond with his baby if he sees the birth
If he is not comfortable with you now, he is probably better not coming in for delivery

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Effective timing of contractions is undertaken by placing the fingers lightly on the fundus of the uterus. This is because the fundus is the a) Most accessible area to feel
options: Area that never fully relaxes
Most contractile part of the uterus
Portion where there is least discomfort
Area where the upper and lower segments meet

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Stretching and displacement of the tissues of the vulva and perineum
options: 1 and 2
1 and 4
1, 2 and 3
2, 3 and 4

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The doctor has just assessed the cervical dilatation as six centimetres. The woman begins to cry out saying ‘the baby is coming, the baby is coming’ which action should the nurse take
options: Tell her to relax
Give her analgesic
Examine the perineum
Ask her partner to calm her
Wheel her into the delivery suite

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs finau, a samoan, is admitted to hospital in labour. Her husband and mother in law are in the waiting room. The best way to provide support for mrs finau is to a) Ask her husband to be with her
options: Check often but allow her to labour alone
Ask her mother in law to be with her
Spend time with her throughout her labour, providing companionship

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Record the fetal heart rate
options: 1 and 5
2 and 5
3, 4 and 5

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following should not be done under any circumstances during the third stage of labour
options: Express clots after the placenta is out
Let the mother ‘push’ the placenta out unaided
Use cord traction and simultaneously push the fundus down
Pull gently on the cord after the cord has lengthened
Wait longer than 5 minutes before delivering the placenta

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: This relates to mother and infant. What preliminary safety precaution must the nurse observe before giving an ampoule of anti D serum to a woman who recently gave birth
options: Wash her hands
Sight the doctors prescription
Collect the equipment for giving the anti D
Check it with the nurse in charge
Ensure the prescription is written in triplicate on the patients chart

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What must happen to the newborn baby before it is taken from the delivery room
options: Identified by name
Put to the mothers breast
Shown to the patient
Checked for skin lesions
Wrapped up firmly on his side

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: To whom is the ‘notification of birth’ form forwarded after completion
options: Senior medical adviser
Medical officer of health
Hospital social worker
Medical officer of obstetrics
Registrar of births, deaths and marriages

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A newborn baby is cyanosed and appears not to be breathing. Which of the following is the appropriate first action to take a) Go to find assistance
options: Clear the airway by suctioning
Commence mouth to mouth resuscitation
Administer oxygen via a nasal catheter
Check to see whether he has an atresia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which statement best describes the basis for maternal bonding in the neonatal period
options: Parental acceptance of the baby
Maternal recognition of the baby
Stimulation of the maternal reflex
Establishment of successful breast feeding
Maintenance of contact between mother and child

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which nursing action is essential before giving the baby an intragastric tube feed
options: Check the feed has been warmed
Place him in a semi prone position
Check the tubing is in the stomach
Run sterile water through the tubing
Place air into the stomach via the tubing

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Signs of sepsis in the infant would include all the following except
options: Irritability
Constipation
Abnormal temperature
Poor sucking reflex and feeding
Irregular respirations or periods of apnoea

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Relate of nursing in the community. Which is the most appropriate response by the nurse making her first home visit to a newborn baby and mother when she learns from a neighbour that the mother and baby are at a tangi on the local marae a) Leave a note to say she called
options: Leave a message with the neighbour
Visit the marae in search of mother and baby
Wait for the mother and baby to return from the tangi
Leave a note with your phone number and date of next visit

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A four year old has been discharged from hospital after having swallowed his fathers blood pressure tablets. Which is the most important advice for the nurse to give when making a follow up home visit
options: Keep all medicines in a locked cupboard
Take out of the bottle only the dose required each time
Use child resistant containers for all medicines
Dispose of unwanted medicines or chemicals safely
Return substances to the medicine cabinet immediately after use

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Greeting male members of the family first
options: 1 and 2
1 and 4
2 and 3
3 and 4

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which information source provides most knowledge about the health problems of a community
options: Data on environmental pollution
The prevalence of unemployment
The standard of available housing
The local health groups
Mortality and morbidity statistics

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: If a child tips boiling water over herself what is the most appropriate first aid action to take
options: Remove her clothing
Apply a soothing lotion
Pour cold water over the burn
Cover the burnt area with clean sheets

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What action should the nurse take when a three home visits the mother of nine months old baby prevents him from being seen as ‘he is sleeping’ a) Question neighbours closely
options: Notify the social welfare of the situation
Notify the family doctor in writing of this occurrence
Insist on seeing the child and refuse to leave the home
Respect the patients right to accept or refuse treatment

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse is working in a children ward. Brian, aged 5 years, is admitted to hospital with burns to his legs, arms and lower abdomen. What is the purpose of an intravenous infusion commenced while brian is in the accident and emergency department
options: To correct hypovolaemia
To administer packed cells
To quickly obtain blood samples
To quickly administer pain relief
To administer large doses of hydrocortisone

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: 200ml of barts solution is prescribed to infuse over 3 hours. The drip factor is 60 drops per ml. How many drips per minute should be given
The rate of the intravenous infusion is less than that prescribed and also approximately 2 hours behind the ordered schedule. The best action by the nurse is to
options: Consult the physician concerning a new schedule for the intravenous infusion
Calculate a new drip rate so that within a 24 hour period. The total amount of ordered solution will be infused
Increase the drip rate so that the total amount of ordered solution will be infused within an 4 hour period
Restart the drip rate to the prescribed rate so the total ordered amount for the 4 hour period will be infused
Allow the transfusion to proceed at a slower rate to prevent over hydration

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which body reaction will occur if the blood pressure of a very shocked person with severe burns is allowed to remain low a) Renal failure
options: Dehydration
Spastic colon
Deep vein thrombosis
Protein loss from the burned areas

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which blood test is used to help estimate the amount of fluid replacement required a) Hematocrit level
options: Complete blood count
Blood creatinine level
Blood oxygen tension (pO2)
Leukocyte differential count

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The main aim in the treatment of a partial thickness burns will be to prevent a) Infection
options: Haemorrhage
Inflammation
Blistering
Discolouration

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which electrolyte is lost from the body in the largest amount during the first 48 hours following a severe burn a) Sodium
options: Calcium
Potassium
Magnesium
Phosphorus

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which part of the skin contains the injured nerve endings and receptor cells which cause the pain following a burn a) Dermis
options: Underlying muscle
Subcutaneous layer
Horny layer of the epidermis
Basal cell layer of the epidermis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Necrotic tissue in a burnt area supports clostridium tetani. A characteristic of the clostridium tetani organisms is their ability to a) Acidify body fluids
options: Agglutinate red blood cells
Cause destruction of muscle tissues
Live without the presence of oxygen
Take up sodium ions from body tissues

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Penicillin 125mgms is prescribed prophylactically. The drug available in powdered form is reconstituted to contain 600mg in 2ml. What amount should be given a) 0.23ml
options: 0.4ml
0.7ml
0.8ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Brian is found to have a chest infection. The micro organism is sensitive to gentamycin sulphate. Brian is charted 8mg BD. The ampoule in the ward is labelled 80mg in 2 ml. What volume should be given a) 0.2ml
options: 0.4ml
0.8ml
1.0ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which is the main reason for a person recovering from burns needing a high protein diet
options: Prevents infection
Rebuilds damaged tissue
Assists with utilisation of vitamins and minerals
Prevents contractures developing
Improves the use of available iron to overcome anaemia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Respiratory difficulties can most effectively be relieved by agents which produce
options: Bronchodilation
Increased oxygen tension
Decreased production of mucous
Increased production of mucous
An action against causative allergens

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Thirty minutes after the intravenous medication is commenced mr jones is anxious, restless and dyspnoeic; respiratory rate is 36. He is still wheezing and using his accessory respiratory muscles. What is the most appropriate decision for the nurse to make
options: He needs to use his inhaler as a supplementary aid
He needs a higher concentration of oxygen
Lack of treatment response requires medical review
He needs physiotherapy to aid effective breathing

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When using a ventolin inhaler, it is important to do all of the following except
options: Shake the inhaler before using it
Expire fully before inhaling the spray
Hold the aerosol within ones open mouth
Use the inhaler repeatedly until some relief is felt

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which behaviour may the nurse observe in mr jones shortly before he has an asthma attack
options: Greater restfulness
Increased irritability
A sense of contentment
Decreased independence
A sense of superiority

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The most important factor about his prognosis that mr jones should know is that he
options: Has an unpredictable prognosis
Will never be ‘completely’ cured
May experience other disabling symptoms
Will require ongoing stress therapy
Can recover but under stress attacks may recur

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Aminophylline is used in the treatment of asthma mainly because it
options: Improves the action of the heart
Dries up the bronchial secretions
Relaxes the smooth muscles of the airways
Stimulates the respiratory centre of the brain
Relieves the persons anxiety and restlessness

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The role of parent surrogate is most therapeutic when the nurse
options: Respects the need for dependence and fosters this need
Avoids restricting the behaviour and makes decisions for him
Allows a completely permissive environment, to encourage the person to take responsibility for himself
Allows the patient to be dependent as long as necessary, but encourages independence as soon as possible

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What is the first action of the nurse who is about to give jeff an 8 year old, his pre medication when she notices crumbs around his mouth a) Check for any food in his locker

Give the pre medication and then report your observation

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse is working in a medical area. Mr jones, aged 53 years, was admitted with an acute attack of asthma. How does asthma affect respiration a) Lessens the expulsion action of cilia

Prevents full use of respiratory muscles
Obstructs the flow of air through the airways

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which is the major pathophysiological abnormality occurring in asthma
options: Cardiac arrhythmias
Bronchiole dysplasia
Inflammation of the alveoli
Constriction of the pleural lining
Spasm of the smooth muscles of the bronchi

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Breathing in asthma is commonly described as
options: Wheezing
Stertorous
Grunting
Gasping
Gurgling

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: All of the following are side effects of aminophylline except
options: Nausea
Headache
Insomnia
Hypertension

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr jones requires digoxin for a heart condition. What effect does the drug digoxin have
options: Lower the blood pressure
Raises the blood pressure

Increases and strengthens the heart beat
Increases and regulates the heart beat

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr jones asks why his pulse rate is noted before each dose of digoxin. Which is the most appropriate explanation for him
options: There is really nothing to worry about
We want to see if you are having sufficient of the drug
If you have tachycardia it would be dangerous to give you the dose
If your pulse is rather slow, it may indicate that the drug is accumulating in your body
If your pulse is too slow the doctor may have charted the incorrect dosage of the drug

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The doctor orders 1000 mls of barts to be infused over 8 hours. The drip factor is 15. What is the number of drops per minute a) 3
Mr jones says he feels very depressed. What aspects of his thinking/behaviour should be explored with mr jones
options: His interactions and feelings toward other members of the household
His thoughts and feelings about his illness
The reasons for allowing depressing thoughts and feelings to overcome him
Religious beliefs about life and death
Recent interactions with members of his own family

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse is asked to administer 15,000 international units of heparin to mr jones. The ampoule contains 25,000 international units in one millilitre. Which amount should be given
options: 0.2ml
0.6ml
0.8ml
1.2ml
1.6ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr jones has a cardiac arrest. In performing external cardiac compression in adults, downward vertical pressure is exerted on the heart by
options: Pushing the fleshy part of the clenched fist on the lower sternum and the heel of the other hand on top of it
Placing the heels of each hand side by side. Extending the fingers over the chest
Putting the heel of one hand on the lower sternum and the heel of the other hand on top of it
Placing the heel of one hand on the xiphisternum and the heel of the other hand on top of it
Spreading the fingers of one hand on the lower sternum and the fingers of the other hand on top of them

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr jones dies. The best answer to a telephone caller asking the condition of mr jones is to
options: Say the patient is deteriorating rapidly
Say that the patient has just died and express condolences
Ask them to hold the line while a senior nurse is called
Say you cannot provide any further information about the patient
Ask if the caller is a relation, then tell them the patient is dead

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What action should be taken in circumstances where a person is wearing a registered nurses medal to which she is not entitled
options: Tell the principal nurse at your hospital
Ignore the situation as you do not want to get involved
Ask the person what she is doing wearing a registered nurses medal
Go to her employer, and tell him that you know she is not a registered nurse
Write to the nursing council giving her name and the name of her place of employment

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse is working in a surgical ward. jeremy, aged 14 years is admitted to hospital with a fractured leg following a car accident. Jeremy is in a shocked condition due to blood loss. He is hyperventilating. Which of the following recordings indicate shock
options: Blood pressure 110/70, respiration 34, pulse 120
Blood pressure 128/90, respiration 32, perspiring
Blood pressure 120/80, pulse 70, skin cold and clammy
Blood pressure 78/56, pulse 152, weak, thread perspiring
Pulse 84, irregular, skin hot and dry, voided 50 mls clear urine

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Hyperventilation may initially cause
options: Metabolic acidosis
Metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory failure
Respiratory acidosis
Respiratory alkalosis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Without describing to them what is involved, the surgeon asks for consent for surgery from jeremys parents. What is your responsibility in this situation a) Ensure the parents has been given appropriate information
options: Question the validity of this consent
Ensure the consent form is completed
Check whether the parents have any questions about the surgery

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jeremy is prescribed pethidine 75mgs intramuscularly as a premedication. The drug is available in ampoules containing 100mgs in 2ml. What dosage should be administered a) 0.125ml
options: 1.5ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse believes the drug dose prescribed for Jeremy is incorrect. The best action to take is
options: Refuse to give the medication
Give the medication as prescribed by the doctor
Withhold the medication and check the dosage with the doctor
Check the drug dosage against another patients chart
Give the medication and consult a current drug handbook

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: After the operation a traffic officer comes to the ward and asks to interview Jeremy in regard to the car accident. What is the appropriate action a) Direct him to jeremys room
options: Be present during the interview
Ensure jeremys parents are present during the interview
Assess whether Jeremy is well enough to be interviewed

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A reporter from a local paper phones the ward and asks for information on jeremys condition. What is the appropriate response in this circumstance a) Jeremy has a broken leg but is comfortable
options: Ill go and get the senior nurse on duty who will assist you with your queries
I cannot give you any information
Please contact the senior medical adviser for such information

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs lever, aged 72 years was admitted for removal of a cataract from her right eye. Which statement best defines the term cataract a) Severely increased pressure within the eye
options: clouding or opacity of the crystalline lens
Incoordinated action of muscles of the eyeball
Ulceration of the cornea secondary to infection
Low grade bacterial infection of the iris and ciliary body

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which physiological change is mrs lever likely to have noted
options: Gradual blurring of vision
Severe unilateral headaches
Floating spots before the eyes
Halo effects around bright lights
Itching and increased watering of her eyes

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which post operative behaviour will mrs lever be protected from if shown the room and ward layout on admission a) Boredom
options: Hostility
Depression
regression
Disorientation

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A cataract in an older person is probably due to
options: Low grade infection
Endocrine imbalance
Mechanical trauma of the lens
Degenerative changes of the lens
Increased intra ocular pressure

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Atropine eye drops 1% are instilled into the eye pre operatively to produce the condition of
options: Decreased tearing
Papillary dilation
Palpebral relaxation
Capillary constriction
Decreased intra ocular pressure

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is your responsibility when preparing mrs lever for surgery
options: Obtaining consent for the surgery
Giving an explanation of the surgery
Advising on alternative treatments
Ensuring the patient understands the surgery

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Despite your explanation to mrs lever about her pre medication, she insists she does not want it. Your response is to
options: Tell mrs lever she cannot have surgery without pre medication
Take mrs lever to the operating theatre and tell the nurse she has not had pre medication
Advise her doctor that she does not wish to have pre medication
Ask her husband to persuade her to have the pre medication

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Pethidine has been ordered for severe headache. When should the nurse give the pethidine
options: Only when the headache becomes very severe
Every four hours whether mrs lever needs it or not
Not more often than six hourly to prevent her becoming addicted
When mrs lever says the headache is unbearable and asks for an analgesic
As often as necessary to keep mrs lever comfortable and control restlessness

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The misuse of drugs regulations 1977 states that controlled drugs should be stored in a
options: Locked metal cupboard fixed to the building
Locked safe, within a locked cupboard designated for dugs
Specified locked cupboard in an area designated for drug administration
Locked metal cabinet on drug trolley

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When counting the pethidine ampoules you discover that there is one short. Your responsibility in this situation is to
options: Check with the pharmacist who did the restock
Record the correct stock in the drug register
Withhold giving the pethidine until the loss is accounted for
Tell the nurse in charge and document the loss

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In what circumstance may a nurse be convicted in a court of law under the misuse of drugs act 1975
options: Giving prescribed sedation to a patient in hospital
Possessing a controlled drug, not prescribed for the nurse by a medical practitioner
Signing the controlled drug register, having given a prescribed medication
Administering a controlled drug under medical guidance in an emergency
Refusing to give a controlled drug to a patient suffering from chronic pain

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You return to the office to find a stranger reading mrs levers notes. What should you do first
options: Remove the notes from the person
Ask the person to identify themselves
Request that the person leave the office
Check whether other notes have been disturbed

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Robert Obrien, 49 years old, has early cirrhosis of the liver due to 10 years of alcohol abuse. After recent blank out spells he admits himself to the alcohol unit for treatment. The nurse observes withdrawal symptoms that require immediate intervention. Which would be the best approach when giving the prescribed medication
options: Gain his cooperation by explaining the procedure
Give him the injection when he is not aware
Restrain his arms and legs with restraints
Explain and have other staff members restrain him

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Obrien reacts angrily to being told he will need further treatment and must remain in the hospital another week. He blames the staff for this setback. Which plan would be most therapeutic
options: Telling him to calm down when he has these outbursts
Encouraging expression of his true feelings
Leaving him alone until he calms down
Explaining to him why these treatments are necessary

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs Obrien asks the nurse what to do if she smells alcohol on her husbands breath after he is discharged. Which response would best help mr Obrien and his wife work through his periods of relapse
options: Confront Robert whenever he has been drinking
Talk about neutral topics and show an interest in him
Tell him to go to his room and sleep
Call his boss and make excuses for his absences

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Obrien is admitted 1 year later with jaundice, ascites and peripheral oedema. While taking his social history he states he is impotent the nurse should recognize that
options: Impotency is of psychogenic origin
Impotency is a symptom of cirrhosis of the liver
Antidepressants can cause impotency
Male impotency shows a sharp decline after the age of 40

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The laboratory studies indicate an increase in mr obriens circulating oestrogens. A symptom associated with this is a) Gynecomastia
options: Hirsutism
Increased libido
Thrombophlebitis

options: Jaundice
Abdominal girth

options: Left side
Stomach

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Joeys mother asks the nurse if she will spoil him by holding him whenever he starts to cry. The nurse should reply that it is most important to prevent crying at this time a) Therefore, spoiling him should not be the major concern
options: However, once his lip has healed he should be allowed extra crying time
Furthermore he needs extra holding and cuddling because he cannot suckle
