options: Sterile water
Skimmed milk and water
Dilute formula

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Roberts parents ask if he will always have a sensitive stomach. The nurse should respond that the prognosis is excellent
options: But he will need close medical supervision until solid foods are his main source of nutrition
Provided he learns to eat slowly and remains sitting for 1 hour after meals
Although a revision will probably be required during the rapid growth period of adolescence

options: Even though problems rarely occur during the second trimester
Because toxaemia usually occurs at this time and can be controlled if recognised early

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Lisa tells the nurse that she has gained 2 kg in a month and plans to diet by skipping lunches. Which of the following responses would be the most appropriate a) Have you noticed that your hands and feet have become swollen
options: You should cut down on high calorie foods like cake and candy, but you shouldn’t skip lung
Your weight gain is just right for you for this period of your pregnancy, you are doing fine
Your supposed to gain 2 kgs of weight its good for the baby youll lose it after the baby is born

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: 50mg is equal to
options: 0.5 gram
5 grams
5000 micrograms

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse observes mr wolfes monitor and identifies asystole. This arrhythmia requires urgent attention because the heart is a) Beating very rapidly
options: Beating very slowly

options: Ensure the airway is clear

options: Thoracic

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Carbon dioxide acts as a

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The antidote to heparin is
options: Vitamin D
Vitamin K

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Blood tinged sputum
options: 1, 2 and 3
1 and 2
All of the symptoms
1, 3 and 5

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: TB is spread by
options: Inhalation of droplets
Ingestion of contaminated food
Injection with unsterile equipment

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following complications may occur if mr Thomas fails to take his medications regularly
options: Allergic reactions to his medications

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A possible toxic effect of streptomycin is

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Susan aged 16 years was admitted for investigation of grand mal epilepsy following a seizure and complaining of blurred vision. The most important test to diagnose epilepsy would be
options: An electroencephalogram

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The site of vision in the brain is located in the

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following medication may be given to prevent a grand mal seizure a) Dilantin

Neocytamen

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Following a grand mal seizure susan is likely to be
options: Hostile

Euphoric

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Susans mother asks you will this trouble make susan slow in school which response would be most appropriate
options: Absolutely not. Susans disease has nothing to do with her intelligence
So long as she has small seizures they will have no effect on her brain
There is no reason to expect the disease to decrease susans ability to learn
As epilepsy causes mental deteriorations, susans learning ability may be affected

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Millie crowe a nursing student develops muscular weakness in her right arm and intermittent urinary incontinence. The diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is made. The pathology underlying the manifestations of multiple sclerosis has been identified as the
options: Deficiency of neurotransmitters
Destruction of the nerve myelin sheath

Premature destruction of transmitter substance

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When discussing the future with millie it is important to explain that multiple sclerosis
options: Is a disorder that becomes progressively worse
Is caused by an underlying viral infection
Can be cured with appropriate treatment
Has remissions of months or years

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The main goal in treating millie is to minimize the risk of
options: Prolonged discomfort
Symptom exacerbation
Delayed recovery
Dehydration

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The persons who are most likely to have the greatest effect in assisting millie to maintain a positive self concept are
options: The occupational therapists during job retraining
Other people with multiple sclerosis who manage independent lives

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr green 56 years old has been in hospital for two weeks with a diagnosis of cerebral thrombosis. His symptoms include expressive aphasia, right sided paralysis and loss of the gag reflex. As part of the long term planning the nurse should

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs green seems unable to accept the idea that her husband must be encouraged to do things for himself. The nurse may be able to work around these feelings by a) Telling mrs green to let her husband do things for himself

Letting mrs green assume the responsibility as she sees fit

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A public health nurse has been invited to talk about child health with a group of mothers. Which is the single most important factor in the early social development of children

The way their needs are met by others

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: An important factor which makes two year old children feel physically secure is

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Parents are likely to have less conflict with their adolescent children if they

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A man has a bleeding socket after getting his tooth removed. the correct action to take is to

Give him a warm saline mouthwash

options: Strongly recommended as sea water is healing
Risky because of the contaminants in sea water
Not acceptable because of the risk of chilling and shock

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A 42 year old farmer is pinned under his tractor. His breathing is laboured, he is slightly cyanosed, shocked and has severe chest pain. While waiting for the doctor the nurse should especially note any a) Alteration in pain

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The farmer is removed from behind the wheel. He is in severe respiratory distress and is becoming more cyanosed. The farmer is found to have an open pneumothorax. The most appropriate first aid is to
options: Seal the wound in the chest wall
Start mouth to mouth resuscitation
Place the farmer in recovery position
Lie the farmer flat, extending his neck

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The ambulance driver gives the farmer oxygen therapy. This improves his respirations and decreases his degree of acidosis by decreasing the
options: Carbon dioxide and carbonic acid in the blood and the ratio of carbonic acid to bicarbonate
Hydrogen ion concentration in the blood and increasing the ratio of carbonic acid to bicarbonate
Carbonic acid, so chloride moves into the red cells leaving more sodium available to form bicarbonate
Build up of potassium in the blood stream and increasing oxygenation of the haemoglobin in the blood cells

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which statement would best help a mother who says that she does not believe in immunisation because it is unnatural
options: Your children are in danger of infection if they were not given breast milk to gain natural immunity
Immunisation assists the body to produce its own immunity and give protection against dangerous infections
If your children are not immunised they will have to be kept away from other children because they could make other children ill
If you do not have your children immunised they can be admitted to hospital with infectious diseases and cost the country a lot of money

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse should explain to a youth who has not been immunised against tetanus that he will be given a
options: Single dose of tetanus serum
Single dose of tetanus toxoid
Small dose of tetanus anti toxin
Course of tetanus toxoid injections

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Vaccinations are often given at specified intervals with weeks or months in between each injection because
options: This is convenient to the doctors and nurses
A stronger secondary response is induced
This is a long standing medical procedure
The body could not cope with a large dose at one time

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Vaccines induce immunity that is
options: Active artificially acquired
Passive artificially acquired
Active naturally acquired
Passive naturally acquired

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following signs/symptoms would indicate mumps
options: Swelling of the lymph nodes
Tenderness of the parotid gland
Enlargement of the prostate gland
Ulceration of vesicular stomatitiis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which option is important for the nurse to know with regard to prevention of the spread of mumps
options: Safe disposal of all bodily excretions
No specific isolation measures are needed
Control of all food stuffs prepared for sale
Isolation for ten days after the last notified case

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is the best description of a vaccine
options: Dead modified bacilli
Live attenuated virus
Dead virus given orally
Antibodies suspended in serum

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs shaw brings her 8 year old daughter jane to the clinic. Jane has eczema. Janes eczema is most likely the result of
options: Inadequate skin care and hygiene
Excretion of acids through sweat pores
An inherited predisposition to skin infections
Sensitivity to a substance in her external environment

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Eczema is the term used to describe a (n)
options: Acute, contagious inflammation of the skin
Excretion of acids through sweat pores
An inherited predisposition to skin infections
Sensitivity to a substance in her external environment

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Eczema is the term used to describe a (n)
options: Acute, contagious inflammation of the skin
Non contagious inflammatory response of the skin
Fungal infection more commonly seen in childhood
Condition marked by the appearance of erythematous wheals

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which statement best describes ‘vesicle’
options: Reddened, pinprick like rash
Small round area of discolouration
Small area of swelling on the skin
Small blister filled with serous fluid

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You are employed as a practice nurse. A friend telephones and asks if her boyfriend has been to see the doctor this week. Your most appropriate response is a) I don’t know
options: Ill have to ask the doctor
I am not able to tell you that
Just a moment ill check the files

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs adams suffers from dementia and requires a dressing to a shin wound. The nurse suspects the wound is the result of a non accidental injury. What is the main cause of non accidental injury in an elderly person suffering from dementia a) A dependent person being more prone to injury
options: A long standing pattern of comestic violence
The home not being a suitable place for a dependent person
The increased stress in caring for a dependent person at home

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When dressing the shin wound the nurse most appropriate remark is
options: How did you scrape your shin mrs adams
How did you scrape your wifes shin mr adams
This shin must hurt. Was it really an accident
A shin is easy to hurt. How did this injury happen

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The most appropriate way to help mr and mrs adams at the first visit is to
options: Express professional concern at the cause of the injury
Conceal feelings about the possible cause of the injury
Reassure mrs adams that this injury will not occur again
Acknowledge the stress on mr adams in caring for his wife

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: An increased incidence of vaginal infections occurs when contraceptive pills are taken because there is
options: A shift in the vaginal pH
Drying of the vaginal mucosa
An increase in vaginal fluids
A reduction in white cell numbers

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What action should the nurse take when on three home visits the mother of a nine months old baby prevents him from being seen as ‘he is sleeping’ a) Notify the social welfare of the situation
options: Notify the family doctor in writing of this occurrence
Insist on seeing the child and refuse to leave the home
Respect the patients right to accept or refuse treatment

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which is the major pathophysiological abnormality occurring in asthma
options: Cardiac arrhythmias
Bronchiole dysplasia
Spasm of the smooth muscles of the bronchi
Inflammation of the alveoli

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Aminophlline is prescribed. Each ampoule contains 250 mg in 10ml. How should be added to the intravenous solution a) 12ml
options: 14ml
16ml
35ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Jillians intravenous infusion of 300ml normal saline is due to run over 4 hours. The drop factor is 60. How many drops per minute must be given for the IV to be completed on time a) 55
Salbutamol (ventolin) is administered through a nebuliser four hourly. The primary action of this drug is as a a) Broncho dilator
options: Cardiac stimulant
Respiratory stimulant
Respiratory depressant

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A client is charted nitrazepam (mogadon) tablets to sleep. She refuses to take them at 9pm. She tells you that the other nurses always leave the tablets on the locker and she takes them when she is ready. What should you do a) Put them back in the container
options: Give her the tablets and let her take them later
Tell the patient to ring when she is ready for them
Tell her if she doesn’t take them now she may not get them later

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Hyperventilation may initially cause
options: Metabolic acidosis
Metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory acidosis
Respiratory alkalosis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Angela Roberts aged 9 years fell off a ladder whilst trying to put a fairy on the Christmas tree. Although angela hit her head when she fell she was fully conscious when her mother found her. Her left arm was very painful, she could not move it, but otherwise, apart from being very pale and frightened, she seemed unhurt. Mrs Roberts took angela to the accident and emergency department of the local hospital. There it was found that she had sustained a greenstick fracture of the midshaft of the left radius and ulna. Bearing in mind what we know of angela which one of the following observations would it be most important for the nurse to maintain accurately after angela has been admitted to the childrens ward a) Temperature
options: Blood pressure
Power and movement of her lower limbs
Size and reaction of her pupils

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A greenstick fracture is defined as one in which the
options: Bone is bent but there is not break in the continuity of the compact tissue of periosteum
Bone is broken at one side and bent at the other
Periosteum is completely severed while the underlying compact tissue is unbroken
Periosteum and compact tissue are not broken but the underlying bone marrow is damaged

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which one of the following is associated with the greatest risk of damage to the brachial artery
options: Dislocated of shoulder
Dislocation of elbow
Mid shaft fracture of radius
Supracondylar fracture of humerus

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A comminuted fracture is defined as one which always
options: Communicates with an open wound
Has the bone broken into more than two pieces
Causes injury to the surrounding organs
Has the fractured ends of the bone driven into each other

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: After he had seen the xrays thehouse surgeon explained to mr and mrs Roberts that he would need their permission to get angelas arm in a good position, and apply plaster of paris. He also explained that in view of the fact that angela had fallen from a height he would prefer to keep her in hospital overnight for observation, but providing there were no complications she could go home the following day. Prior to having the plaster applied, angelas arm was manipulated. In this situation, manipulation is a term which implies
options: An open surgical operation to ensure the bone fragments are in a good position and not trapping any nerves or blood vessels
Movement of the fragments of the bone, at the fracture site until they are in a good position for healing
The insertion of guide wires to ensure that the bone is in perfect alignment
Violent forceful movements of the injured arm to free the bone fragments from surrounding ligaments and so prevent adhesions

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is the most important feature in the drying of angelas cast
options: Avoid covering the plaster with plastic sheeting
Ease the plaster with bending shears at the first sign of swelling of the fingers
When touching the plaster, use only the palm of the hands
Avoid using any forms of hot convection air currents

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: If angela complains of tingling and itching inside her plaster at a point level with the head of the ulna, which of the following explanations should the nurse suspect first. The symptoms are probably caused by
options: A perfectly natural return of sensation following the original injury
The early stages of a pressure sore forming
Damage to the peripheral sensory nerve supply

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: With reference to the healing of a fracture, which of the following statements is true
options: Callus formation is the first stage of repair
The first stage of repair is haematoma formation, which is gradually replace by granulation tissue
A broken bone will eventually unite and be restored to full function, but the torn periosteum will never repair

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs skinner 43 years, is diagnosed as having rheumatoid arthritis. Which of the following statements is true regarding rheumatoid arthritis a) Equally common in both sexes
options: More common in women than men
Rare in young adults
Never occurs in children

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Rheumatoid arthritis and osteo arthritis (osteo arthrosis) differ in that rheumatoid arthritis
options: Is usually associated with systemic disturbance
Usually results from injury to a joint
Affects mainly larger weight bearing joints

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: With reference to rheumatoid arthritis, which of the following statements is true
options: There is no known cure for this condition
A common complication of this condition is damage to the valves of the heart
Primary symptoms occur within 10 days of the patient having a haemolytic streptococcal infection
Involvement of the joints or the cervical vertebrae is rate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The stiffness associated with rheumatoid arthritis is typically described as
options: Better after resting
Bad in the morning and gets worse as the day progresses
At its worst in the morning and improves as the day progresses

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following analgesics is most commonly prescribed for patients with rheumatoid arthritis a) Aspirin
options: Pethidine
Meralen (flufenamic acid)

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs skinner was later in hospital for six weeks. During this time her general condition improved considerably. She was discharged, arrangements were made for her to attend physiotherapy. Which of the following is of prime importance in the care of the patient during an acute (active) phase of rheumatoid arthritis a) Rest the body and the affected limbs
options: Rest the body but give vigorous active exercises to the affected limbs
Apply splints to the affected limbs

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: During the (acute) phase of rheumatoid arthritis the patient should be nursed in which of the following positions a) Upright
options: Recumbent
Lateral

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When mrs skinner attended the physiotherapy department as an outpatient, she was given local applications of heat. The main purpose of this form of treatment is to a) Produce sufficient temporary pain relief to enable the patient to perform her exercises
options: Increase the range of movement to the affected joints without the need of active exercises
Increase the supply of white cells to the affected joints and so reduce inflammation
Reduce swelling of the joint

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Six years have passed and twice in recent years mrs skinner has been admitted to hospital. The first time for an arthrodesis of the left knee and the second time for an arthroplasty of the right knee. The purpose of an arthrodesis is to provide a joint which
options: Have a full range of movement
Has a limited range of movement
Is stable but not moveable

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following activities is mrs skinner most likely to need help as a result of having had an arthrodesis of the knee a) Putting on her shoes
options: Using the toilet
Washing her legs
Cutting her toe nails

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Following arthrodesis of the knee, the most difficult action for a patient to perform is
options: Standing
Walking
Rising from a chair to the standing position
Turning over in bed

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is the most important duty of the nurse caring for mrs skinner in the immediate post operative period a) Maintain a clear airway
options: Record her pulse and blood pressure ½ hourly
Prevent her from moving her legs

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs skinner has a blood transfusion in progress following hip replacement. Her blood group is A. This means that in an emergency she could receive blood from a) Any other group
options: Any group except B
Group A only

options: Give her an extra blanket
Send for medical aid

options: To become a carrier

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The jaundice in hepatitis A is best described as
options: Haemolytic
Bilio-static
Obstructive

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The incubation period is
options: Less than 10 days
5-15 days
15-50 days
40-60 days

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: During the infectious stage, a person with hepatitis A is excreting the virus mainly in
options: Faeces
Urine
Saliva

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When a person is in the infectious stage of hepatitis A, special precautions are taken when you

Where joe once had been a moderately bright student with a small circle of friends, his teacher reported that joe had become less communicative. Which of the following is psychologically significant and requires further assessment

Joes concern about the world

less co operative, more inclined to get angry

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: joe looks worried and tells you that he can cause terrible things to happen just by thinking about them. To prove this, he relates when he is thinking about aeroplanes and one crashed on the same day. Your most therapeutic response would be a) no. Its just a coincidence that the plane crashed

it must be a scary feeling to believe you have that responsibility
that must make you a very powerful person, eh

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: reminding him to change his clothes

2 only

the hypoxic drive is inhibited causing a slowing in breathing rate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: aminophylline comes in ampoules of 250mgs in 10mls. How much in mls, would you draw up to obtain 300mgs a) 8.3

A client is prescribed 1 litre of dextrose/saline to be given over 3 hours. If the IV giving set has a drop factor of 15 drops per ml, which of the following in drops per minute, gives the correct rate a) 17
Cholesterol is frequently discussed in relation to atherosclerosis. Cholesterol is a substance that

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Death following a myocardial infarction is most likely caused by

cardiogenic shock
congestive heart failure

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: which of the following factors increases insulin resistance
options: obesity
hypoglycemia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: in metabolism of carbohydrate, the most important function of insulin is
options: precipitating the breakdown of glycogen in the liver
to facilitate the passage of glucose into the cell
acting as a antagonist to glucagon in the muscle sheath

exposure to dust and pollen
cigarette smoking

hypertension

low fowlers
prone

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Large quantities of frothy blood tinged sputum would indicate which of the following

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In metabolism of carbohydrates, the most important function of insulin is
options: Precipitating the breakdown of glycogen in the liver
To facilitate the passage of glucose in the cell

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following factors increases insulin resistance
options: Obesity
Hypoglycaemia
Decrease in amyloid deposits

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A compensatory mechanisms for respiratory acidosis is

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Evaluation of the effectiveness of cardiac nitrates is based on
options: Relief of anginal pain
A decrease in blood pressure
Improved cardiac output

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Heart failure may be defined as
options: The inability of the heart of pump sufficient blood to the tissues
The inability of the heart to pump sufficient blood to the myocardium
The inability of the atrio ventricular valves to control blood flow within the heart
Inflammation of the endocardium

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs green has an acute episode of right sided heart failure and is receiving frusemide (lasix). The symptoms mrs green most likely displayed on admission are a) Dyspnoea, oedema, fatigue
options: Weakness, palpitations, nausea
Fatigue, vertigo and headache
A feeling of distress when breathing

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse notes that mrs greens abdomen is distended. The nurse should realise that the client with congestive heart failure develops ascites because of a) Increased pressure within the circulatory system
options: Rapid diffusion of solutes and solvents into plasma
Rapid osmosis from tissue spaces to cells
Loss of cellular consituents in blood

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In the systemic circulation, blood returning to the heart from the legs would have to pass through the
options: Right coronary artery
Inferior vena cava
Abdominal aorta
Thoracic aorta

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following factors increases insulin resistance
options: Obesity
Hypoglycemia
Decrease in amyloid deposits
Increase in muscle mass

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following findings would indicate that a person with diabetes might be suffering from neuropathy a) Blurred vision
options: Loss of memory
Numbness of arms
Sensory loss in legs

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: In metabolism of carbohydrate, the most important function of insulin is
options: Precipitating the breakdown of glycogen in the liver
To facilitate the passage of glucose in to the cell
Acting as an antagonist to glucagon in the muscle sheath
Increasing the circulating blood sugar level

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Lasix 15 mg is ordered for a client. Available stocks contain 10mg in a 2ml ampoule. The correct dose would be a) 5ml
options: 3ml
1.5 ml
2.5ml

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: If you suspect the dose of a prescribed medication is too high, your best action would be to
options: Delay giving it until an adequate explanation is given to you about the dosage
Give it once, but don’t repeat the medication until the dosage is confirmed
Give it if the medication is given orally, but delay it if it is given by injection
Give the dose you know is appropriate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Death following a myocardial infarction is most likely caused by
options: Dysrhythmia
Cardiogenic shock
Congestive heart failure
Ventricular rupture

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When collecting a client from post anaesthetic recovery room, the nurse places the highest priority on assessing
options: The patients level of consciousness
The condition of the surgical site
The status of fluid and electrolyte balance
The adequacy of respiratory function

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: DKA occurs when there is
options: A profound lack of insulin in the body
A severe decrease in blood glucose
Insufficient insulin production
Excessively rigid glycemic control

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which symptom of DKA causes patients to seek care
options: Dehydration
Abdominal discomfort
Acetone breath
Blurred vision

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following is a late sign of DKA
options: Diarrhoea
Hypertension
Lethargy
Deep rapid breathing

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What makes HONK so dangerous
options: It has an insidious onset
It presents with a myriad of symptoms
It has a rapid downhill course
It mimics other diabetic problems

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Plasma glucose levels in HONK are usually
options: <11 mmol/L
11-27 mmol/L
>33mmol/L

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The goals for emergency treatment of DKA and HONK include all the following except
options: Correcting the underlying cause
Normalising glucose
Restoring fluid and electrolytes
Stabilising respiratory status

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse should instruct the diabetic patient to follow all of the following sick day guidelines except
options: Drink plenty of caffeine free fluids
Always take your normal dose of insulin even if you cant eat
Monitor blood glucose every six to eight hours
Always take your oral diabetic medications even if you cant eat

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Large quantities of frothy blood tinged sputum would indicate which of the following
options: Suctioning required
Severe pulmonary oedema
Respiratory infection
Pneumothorax

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: An adult patient has damage to the electrical conduction of the ventricles of the heart. The nurse would expect to see changes in a) P wave
options: T wave
Qrs complex
U wave

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: To relieve angina pectoris symptoms, the nurse administers nitroglycerin sublingual to the patient. Which of the following is an action of nitroglycerin a) Decreases myocardial oxygen comsumption
options: Causes venous constriction
Decreases collateral circulation in the heart
Causes arterial constriction

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following may develop in the patient when ketone bodies accumulate in excessive amounts a) Hypovolemia
options: Polyuria
Diabetic ketoacidosis
Blurred vision

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: To gain a postoperative patients co operation in ambulating, coughing, deep breathing, and turning, which intervention is most important for the nurse to perform
options: Administer analgesics freely to achieve the patients relative freedom from pain
Ensure that the patient understands the rationale for these activities
Warn the patient about complications that can occur if the activities are not performed
Praise the patient when the activities are completed

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse is teaching a group cardiac patients to evaluate the nutritional content of food. The nurse explains that if a serving of 100 gram peanut butter has 36 grams of fat and 190 calories the percentage of fat per serving is a) 52%

Mr doncald graham, aged 81, has a large obstruction that occurred as a result of a faecal impaction. During assessment of mr graham, the nurse recognises which finding as consistent with a large bowel obstruction a) Rapid onset of copious vomiting
options: Metabolic alkalosis
Referred pain to the back
Constant, generalised abdominal pain

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The physician orders 2 units of blood to be infused for a client who is bleeding. Before blood administration the nurses highest priority should be a) Obtaining the clients vital signs
options: Allowing the blood to reach room temperature
Monitoring the haemoglobin and hematrocrit levels
Determining proper typing and cross matching of blood

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A feature of type 1 diabetes is
options: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells in pancreas
Late onset usually older than 40 years
Resistance to insulin in target tissues
Obesity

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The percentage of the people with diabetes type 2 out of all diabetic clients is
options: Over 40%
Over 50%
Over 60%
Over 80%

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Type 2 diabetes usually requires
options: Oral hypoglycaemic medications, diet and exercise
Sub cutaneous insulin
Regular daily monitoring of blood sugar levels
Four times daily monitoring of blood sugar levels

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Following surgery, mr J is ready to be transferred from the recovery unit to the surgical ward when
options: The vital signs are established and the temperature is normal
The gag reflex and voluntary movements have returned
His blood transfusion is completed and reflexes are normal
He pushes the airway out and respiration are normal
He regains consciousness and vital signs are stabilised

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: On the way back from the operating theatre mr j stops breathing and becomes very cyanosed. Your best action would be to a) Commence cardiac massage
options: Ensure that his airways are clear
Give oxygen
Send the orderly for medical aid
Return mr j to theatre

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr j is charted pethidine 100 mg for post operative pain. As a registered nurse you have to make the decision about giving the first post operative dose of analgesic. It is generally regarded that this should be given a) Only if the patient asks for it
options: Before the pain becomes too severe
When pain is severe
When the doctor tells you to give it
When the supervisor permits it to be given

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Wound bleeding which occurs seven to ten days post operatively is most likely due to
options: Infection
Defective suturing
Not enough exercise
Premature removal of wound drain
Premature removal of sutures

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following may be the cause for inability to void following lower abdominal surgery
options: Oedma of urethra
Spasm of bladder sphincter
Atony of bladder muscle
Fear
Pressure of the bladder against the pubes

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse notices that the clients surgical wound is swollen and red. The client complains of pain and says it feels warm. This condition is known as a) Maladaption
options: Inflammatory response
Hormonal activity
Exhaustion stage

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A patient develops the following signs 48 hours following surgery 1 progressive (faecal) vomiting 2 marked abdominal distension 3 absence of bowel sounds. What is likely to be wrong with this patient a) Impaction of faeces
options: Paralytic ileus
Irritable bowel
Early peritonitis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The purpose of reversible surgery for ulcerative colitis is to
options: Reduce anaemia
Rest the bowel
Improve the appetite
Alleviate abdominal pain

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: An 82 year old woman is admitted with a fractured hip. She is thin, and her skin has poor turgor; she is alert and cooperative. This client is at risk for developing pressure sores. Which factor increases her risk the most a) A haemoglobin level of 14 g/100ml
options: An adequate muscle mass
The absence of the shearing force
Moisture on the skin

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which intervention would the nurse use to prevent post operative deep vein thrombosis
options: Encourage the client to stay in bed
Maintain skin integrity
Order a sheepskin for the bed
Teach the client to do leg exercises

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurse suspects that a client has a deep vein thrombosis. The nurses initial action is to
options: Document findings in the clients chart
Massage the area
Measure the circumference of the calf
Notify the physician

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following best states the rationale for assessing preoperative vital signs
options: Complies with standard policy for all clients admitted to the hospital
Helps to determine which anesthetic should be given to the client
Provides a baseline to assist in determining problems
Reassures the client that he is being cared for appropriately

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which of the following signs would indicate that mrs Collins is haemorrhaging post operatively
options: Decreased BP, pulse and respirations
Decreased BP, increased pulse and respirations
Increased BP, pulse and respirations
Increased BP, and respirations, decreased pulse

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Dixon, aged 42 years is admitted with alcohol dependency and cirrhosis of the liver. The main aid in the treatment of an alcoholic is to help him to a) Become independent of his dependency on alcohol
options: Become dependent on an alternative support
Give up alcohol and associating with drinkers
Feel completely independent and self sufficient
Realise the hurt his actions have caused his family

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Dixon brings with him his morphine tablets prescribed by his general practitioner. What action should the nurse take
options: Put the bottle on the drug trolley
Take the patient to send them home
Hand them in immediately to be locked up
Tell the patient to keep them in his locker
Put them in her pocket to later give to the charge nurse

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The next day mr Dixon refused to eat in the dining room with other patients, despite suggestions from the nurse. This behaviour is best recorded as a) He is depressed and not eating
options: He was uncooperative and refused to eat with others
He preferred to eat in his room, against nurses advice
The patient seemed withdrawn and did not follow suggestion
He did not eat in the dining room

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What is the cause of ascites in cirrhosis of the liver
options: Renal failure due to back pressure
Biliary obstruction by fibrous tissue
Reduced hepatic synthesis of albumin
Malnutrition due to the lack of protein
Renal failure due to portal hypertension

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A week later you meet mr Dixons neighbour. She tells you that mr Dixon has gone into hospital and asks you what wrong with him .your best response is to a) Tell her that you cannot discuss any details about patients
options: Acknowledge her concern and suggest that she talks to mrs Dixon
Suggest that she rings the ward and enquiries about mr Dixon
Explain to her the symptoms of alcohol dependency

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The first phase of the nurse patient relationship with mr Dixon mainly involves
options: Making contact with him
Determining his wants and needs
Assessing his needs for nursing care
Establishing a therapeutic goal for him
Establishing comfortable rapport with him

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Which behaviour of the nurse will provide the best therapeutic care of mr Dixon
options: Liking every patient she cares for
Accept the patient as a human being
Sympathizing with mr Dixons problems
Keeping a distant professional attitude
Accept mr Dixons maladaptive behaviour

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Dixon finds verbal communication difficult. It would be most helpful and therapeutic to
options: Involve mr Dixon in a group activity so he has a choice of persons to talk to
Focus on mr doxon and his problems and mention similar problems of your own
Ask mr Dixon direct questions which require straight forward concrete answers
Ask several non productive questions that will not make mr dixon feel threatened
Engage in a concurrent activity with mr Dixon in which he can feel more comfortable

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: After a day of abstinence, mr Dixon has coarse tremors of the hands. He asks how long it will be before his ‘shakes go away’. The nurse should base her reply on the fact that the tremors
options: Come and go regardless of treatment
Usually are relieved after two days of abstinence
Can only be relieved by anti parkinsonism medication
Are a permanent condition due to irreversible central nervous system damage
May persist for several days or longer after alcoholic intake has stopped

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Visual, tactile and auditory hallucinations
options: 1 and 2
1, 2 and 3
1, 3 and 4
2, 3 and 4

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Dixon was committed to an institution under the alcoholism and drug addiction act 1966 and is thought well enough to leave hospital prior to the expiry of the commitment to achieve this aim he should a) Apply to the court for early release
options: Be discharged by the admitting officer
Be placed on trial leave by the doctor
Plan to attend the hospital as an outpatient
Plan to attend the national society of alcoholism and drug addiction

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Urine soaked clothing and bedlinen
options: 1 and 2
2 and 5
1, 4 and 5
3, 4 and 5

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: How does alcohol cause indigestion
options: Increased pancreatic enzyme action
Decreased bile production
Irritates the stomach lining
Stimulates the stomach juices
Causes pain from a damaged liver

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Alcoholics anonymous is an organisation which caters for
options: Anyone seeking assistance to overcome an alcohol problem
Anyone who is interested in helping people with alcoholism in the community
Relatives and friends of people with alcoholism who understand how to help them
Religious people who are willing to hive free assistance and counsel to people suffering from alcoholism
Professional people with special skills and understanding about alcoholism and how to overcome it

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: What change does mr Dixon need to make before he can be helped with his drinking problem
options: Decide he wants to stop drinking
Recognise he can control his drinking habits
Be willing to change his way of life and make new friends
Admit that alcohol is causing problems in his life and that he needs help
Accept responsibility for his drinking and face up to his problem

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Dixon is prescribed antabuse. What is the action of antabuse
options: Inhibits albumin production in the liver
Inhibits the metabolism of alcohol by the liver
Induces vomiting by acting on the stomach lining
Interferes with the action of alcohol in the brain
Interferes with the excretion of alcohol form the kidneys

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Antabuse may be prescribed to help a person with a drinking problem to
options: Remove the need for alcoholic beverages
Ease misery so benefits other treatment
Provide a disincentive to take alcohol
Repair body tissues directly affected
Reduce the side effects of alcoholism

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Dixon says that some colleagues have asked him to go out for a drink at the hotel with them. The best response by the nurse is
options: Would you like to spend some time with your colleagues
you definitely must not go, as you have no will power
Go but you are not allowed to drink as you are on antabuse
Would you like to discuss ways of dealing with this request
A few drinks will not hurt. Later we can discuss how you coped

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Dixon feels faint while in the bath. The first action of the nurse should be to a) Call for help
options: Take his pulse
Hold his head out of the water
Pull the plug and let the water out
Get him out of the bath with assistance

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: For several years you have headed a ward where a registered nurse who works hard is well intentioned and safe, but fails to practise at an acceptable level of competence. Several of the staff complain about ‘carrying’ this nurse
options: Tell them to do their own work and not be concerned with others
Tell them to sort it out themselves
Tell them you will have a talk with her about her poor performance
Talk to the nurse and encourage her to try some other form of work
Tell the nurse to speak to the others who are complaining

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: One of the complaining staff says she is going to report this staff member to the principal nurse, before you have had a chance to handle the situation. Do you a) Encourage her to do this
options: Forbid her from doing this
Arrange for you and her to talk to the staff member together
Arrange for all the staff to have a meeting about it with the staff member
Ask the supervisor her advice

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A patient tells you he has heard negative ‘whispers’ about the staff member from other staff. He says her care of him has been exemplary. Do you a) Chastise the gossiping staff
options: Thank the patient and say it will go no further
Use the information when trying to persuade the supervisor to intervene
Do nothing
Use the information positively when approaching the staff member about her standards of care

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The staff member who has been complained about comes to you and says she wants a transfer to another ward as the staff have become unbearable to work with. Do you a) Call all the staff together and challenge them with this
options: Call in the supervisor and ask her to intervene
Use this opportunity to discuss with the staff member how she feels about her standards of care
Say you will arrange a transfer
Arrange for her to have a holiday

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A charge nurse friend of yours tells you this staff member has asked to go to her ward and asks you your opinion of her work ability. Do you a) Praise her work to get rid of her
options: Tell the charge nurse all the negative aspects
Suggest a trial period in another ward
Say she will have to ask nursing administration
Say you will let her have all the work appraisal records with the staff members permission

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Williams is a 48 year old taxi driver who drinks heavily. Recently the pain in his right leg which has become progressively worse, so he sought advise of his general practitioner. The doctor told him he has atherosclerosis and arranged for him to be seen by a specialist. He is then admitted for rest and investigations. Atherosclerosis is best described as
options: An allergic response
A narrowing of the veins
A narrowing of the arteries
An inflammation of the arteries
A blocking of an artery

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The reason to advise mr Williams to stop smoking is because smoking
options: Produces muscle spasm
Lowers cardiac output
Constricts the arterioles
Increases blood carbon dioxide levels
Causes venous stasis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The priority care for mr Williams ischaemic leg is to
options: Maintain complete bed rest
Stop mr Williams from smoking
Improve his peripheral circulation
Protect his leg from injury
Perform regular physiotherapy to the affected leg

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The best advice to give mr Williams on discharge is for him to
options: Exercise regularly
Avoid exposure to cold and excessive heat
Take analgesics every four hours
Wear a supportive bandage
Remain on bed rest at home

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr shaw a newspaper reporter aged 38, is married with three young children. They have their own home and a large garden. Whilst cutting the lawn mr shaw suddenly had severe chest pain and felt unwell. His wife called the doctor who diagnosed a myocardial infarction and sent for the ambulance. Mr shaw was admitted to the coronary care unit. Myocardial infarction is best described as a) Death of heart muscle
options: A clot in the coronary artery
Lack of blood to the heart muscle
Thickening of the arteries of the heart
Spasm of the coronary arteries

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The nurses first action when the oscilloscope connected to a patient suddenly shows a straight line is to a) Initiate CPR
options: Call an emergency
Connect him to another monitor
Give a predcordial thump
Check his pulse rate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The most important observations for the nurse to make when mr shaw returns to the ward to convalesce concern a) His urinary output
options: The amount of exercise he does
The amount of activity that induces heart pain
The amount of food he eats
His pulse rate and blood pressure

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The action potential of each heart beat begins in the
options: Sinoatrial node
Purkinje fibres
Atrioventricular node
Intercalated discs
Fossa ovalus

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Muscle contraction occurs when
options: Myosin is converted into actin
Glucose is converted into muscle glycogen
Actin and myosin slide between each other
Smooth muscle is transformed into skeletal muscle
Hormones are released into the cross bridges

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs E is 60 she has pernicious anaemia. She is admitted to hospital for investigation and treatment. As she is transferred from the wheelchair to her bed the nurse notes her shortness of breath. Her dyspnoea was probably the result of a) Hypoxia
options: Anxiety
Heart failure
Pneumonia
Splenomegaly

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The smooth beefy red appearance of mrs Es tongue is probably due to
options: Low grade infection
Chemical irritations
Mechanical trauma
Vitamin deficiency
Poor oral hygiene

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: A 21 year old male patient called david has been admitted to your ward having been involved in a major house fire. He has suffered severe burns, involving the whole of his trunk, and has sustained a compound fracture of his left femoral shaft. What % of his body area has been burnt a) 9%
At the time of injury david would have most benefited by the following treatment to his burnt area
options: Removing his clothing
Application of cold water
Covering with a clean water
Covering with a clean sheet
Covering burnt area with antiseptic cream f) Soak area in sodium bicarbonate

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: David is a normal healthy adult. What would his haemotocrit (packed cell volume) have been before his accident a) 25%
shock, due to a haemorrhage from a compound fracture of the femur is called
options: neurogenic
oligaemic
vasomotor
toxaemic
anaphylactic

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Slow down or stop IV fluids
options: 1, 2 and 3
2, 3 and 4
3, 4 and 5
1, 3 and 4
1, 4 and 5

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: When davids condition has been stabilized he is to undergo surgery under a general anaesthetic. His most important immediate pre operative care is to ensure that a) His consent form has been signed
options: He has not drunk or eaten anything for 4-6 hours
His relatives have been notified
His pre medication has been given
He has emptied his bowels

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Immediately following surgery the most important role of the recovery nurse is to
options: Record davids pulse and blood pressure
Maintain a clear airway
Observe his dressing for haemorrhage
Assess davids level of consciousness
Give david pain relieving medication

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: David returns to the ward with closed suction drainage to his leg wound. The purpose of closed suction drainage in a surgical wound is to a) Prevent haematoma formation
options: Allow the nurse to measure blood loss accurately
Prevent david from moving the body part operated on
Draw the edges of the wound together
Prevent tissue hypoxia

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Allow wound debridement
options: 1, 2 and 3
2, 3 and 4
1, 3 and 4
2, 3 and 5
2, 4 and 5

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You have a close friend mrs Alexander age 85. While visiting with her she asks you if she can change her dietary habits. You reply that elderly women need a diet that is a) Low in protein, high in fibre
options: High in phosphorus, low in fibre
High in protein, high in calcium
High in thiamine, high in copper
Low in phosphorus, how in calcium

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The majority of elderly clients live in
options: Nursing homes
Boarding homes for the elderly
Their own homes
Retirement villages
Flats for the elderly

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs Alexander complains of constipation and she asks you for suggestions of measures to be used on an occasional basis. You recommend a) Milk of magnesia
options: Soap suds enema
Dulcolax suppositories
Tap water enema
Senekot tablets

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Over the last several months you have noticed that you must talk louder when speaking to mrs Alexander. You are aware that mrs alexanders hearing difficulty is most likely due to
options: Serious otitis media
Conductive deficit
Presbycusis
Otosclerosis
Otitis externa

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: You notice that mrs Alexander also appears lonely. To help alleviate her loneliness you suggest that she
options: Make a life review scrapbook which focuses on important occasions in her life
Join an exercise class for elderly clients at the YMCA
Phone her son who lives in a distant town at least twice a week
Pursue her needlework interest by joining a needlework club
Contact her son and organise a holiday visit with him

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs Alexander states that she is having difficulty sleeping at night. You suggest that she
options: Ask her general practitioner to prescribe a hypnotic
Drink a warm cup of tea prior to bedtime
Engage in an active exercise programme once hour before bedtime
Drink a glass of warm milk at night and take naps as needed
Keep herself awake during the day with plenty of activity

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The skin change which mrs Alexander is most likely to exhibit is
options: Increased elasticity
Decreased number of sweat glands
Increased subcutaneous fat
Decreased number of epidermal cells
Increased melanin production

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mrs Alexander mentions that her skin is dry, particularly in winter. You suggest to her that she
options: Use bath oils each time she bathes
Applies a moisturising cream after her bath
Uses a cooler water temperature when she bathes
Applies an astringent agent after her bath
Take a multivitamin tablet daily

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Matthews (65) is admitted to your ward with the complaint of gradual loss of vision. What occupies most of the anterior chamber of the eye a) Vitreous body
options: Aqueous fluid
Perilymph
Endolymph
Optic disc

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: The pathophysiology of chronic open angle glaucoma is
options: Pressure of the anteriorly displaced iris against the filtration network
Clogging of the aqueous outflow tract with inflammatory debris
Thickening of the meshwork covering the canal of schlemm
Overproduction of aqueous humor by hypertrophied ciliary body
Degeneration of sclera veins preventing absorption of aqueous humor

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Matthews should be advised to protect his eyes for an hour or two following intraocular pressure readings because
options: The weight of the pressure measuring device may rupture sclera vessels
Mechanical irritation of the eye produces severe temporary photophobia
Corneal anaesthesia renders the eye insensitive to the presence of a foreign body
Mineral oil used as a lubricant retards normal lacrimal secretions
His eyes will need time to restore their normal surface tensions following tonometry

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Pilocrpine is effective in treating glaucoma because it
options: Draws the iris away from the cornea allowing aqueous to drain from the anterior chamber
Depresses cells of the ciliary body responsible for aqueous humor production
Relaxes extraocular muscles permitting increase in the diameter of the globe
Closes the opening between the iris and the lens preventing forward movement of the vitreous
Fosters aqueous outflow by dilating the canal of schlemm

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Mr Matthews 40 year old son asks you if he will get glaucoma when he is older. Which of the following responses by the nurse would be most helpful
options: Tell me how you feel about the possibility of your getting glaucoma
You have made a useful observation. It would be a good idea to have your eyes examined now
Scientists haven’t yet worked out all the genetic patterns involved, but glaucoma is inheritable d) In this day and age there are so many diseases which have been found to be inherited
You are obviously worried about your eyesight, so i suggest you have your eyes examined

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: Cathy is 4 years old and is admitted suffering from glomerulonephritis. She has passed red urine at home, has a puffy face and is lethargic and anorexic. Which of the following will be most reduced by bedrest a) Oedema
options: Malaise
Haematuria
Hypertension
Proteinuria

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: It would be most important to know the following about cathy; she has
options: Lost weight since yesterday
Not eaten her lunch
Started vomiting
worsening haematuria
experienced generalised itching

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: one of the following disorders is considered contributory to cathys condition – recent
options: measles
cold sores
red eye
mumps
tonsillitis

exam_questions_set_1.question_text: one of the following foods should be omitted when tempting cathy to eat
